text:
MENTAL HEALTH LINKS BELOW â¬‡ï¸
UPDATED FAQ.
PLEASE READ THROUGH THIS BEFORE YOU MESSAGE US.
Â· Where can I send in a confession?
https://www.crush.ninja/en-us/pages/ucllove/
--------------
Â· I would like something removed/ it is inappropriate/defamation
Please message us with a LINK to the post and we will take it down ASAP. (Usually within the hour.)
To keep the page running, please do not report the post itself (as we could get suspended and It will take awhile for your post to be removed. Our page has nearly been taken down numerous times and itâ€™s easier to just message us tbh. PLEASE DONâ€™T LET US END UP LIKE IMPERIAL SECRETS.)
--------------
Â· Why was my submission not posted?
1. Sometimes submissions never reach us and we never get a chance to post them due to a glitch, if it has not been posted within 2+ days please send it again.
2. We are currently voting on whether to post the confession as it may contain offensive/discriminatory content. This usually takes 30+ hours
3. It broke our guidelines/was voted to be deleted.
4. It was about housing/renting etc
Most confessions are posted and if you are wondering why your submission wasnâ€™t posted then please send it again/message us and we can clarify the issue.
--------------
Â· I would like to co-host/create an event with UCLove.
Message the page and we will see if this is something we can work with.
--------------
Â· Where is this uni dating app people keep mentioning?
https://uni-dating.com
--------------
Â· I think this post should have a trigger warning.
Please message us, similarly we will do our best to tw posts that may contain sensitive content, sometimes things fall through.
--------------
Your GP (general practitioner) is your first point of contact for any issues related to your physical and mental health. You should register with your GP as soon as possible.
If you live in central or north London, you will likely fall within the catchment area for Ridgmount Practice, UCLâ€™s partner health clinic - https://www.ridgmountpractice.nhs.uk/
You can start your student patient registration for Ridgmount Practice online - https://www.visualproductions.org.uk/ucl/reg.html
-----------------------
Â· I am having mental health issues and would like to seek help.
Below are some links to mental health services at UCL:
(If you would like to add some links/helpful services for mental health please message us.)
https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/support-and-wellbeing/wellbeing
https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/support-and-wellbeing/mental-health-and-wellbeing/drop-sessions-and-appointments
https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/support-and-wellbeing/specialist-information-and-support
The Care First support is free of charge and is available:
from 5pm to 9am Monday to Friday
for 24 hours during Weekends
for 24 hours during Bank Holidays and UCL closure periods
For telephone counselling call 0800 197 4510
http://nightline.org.uk/ - has an online chat and helpline they are open from 6pm to 8am every night of term
For online counselling visit Care First Lifestyle where you can access a one-on-one messaging service with a counsellor in real-time. You will need to log in using these details:
username: uclstudent
password: bentham
The Care First service is paid for by UCL and is available only to UCL students. This means that you will be required to provide your name, date of birth and UCL student number in order for a Care First counsellor to be able to help you. Care First must inform UCL Student Support and Wellbeing if a student is at serious risk of harming themselves or someone else.
For more hotlines and links: #uclove40816
--------------
Lastly, we are human, we make mistakes or take ages to post confessions, please be patient and treat us admins with respect, hating on us or being rude wonâ€™t make the situation better nor will it make us want to continue running this page. During busy periods such as exams/holidays we will be posting less frequently, please be patient.
Lots of love,
Admin team
CRUSH.NINJA
UCLove

text:
Iâ€™m disappointed in you guys.
Some of you in the UK will never know what itâ€™s like to be a Black person being stopped by the police for the fifth time - the way you feel anxious (what if you die? Who will see you? Who will hear you?) some of you will never be Asian and called scum or told to â€˜go back to their own countryâ€™ or be a Muslim woman and be called a terrorist for wearing a hijab. Or be assaulted because you caused â€˜coronaâ€™ This is a privilege - itâ€™s a privilege to walk through security without getting stopped, to not feel anxious in a grocery store because someone thinks you are stealing. Itâ€™s a privilege to not feel like wanting to be white - to want desperately to have blue eyes like your classmates rubbing your skin so many times itâ€™s starts to get red.
To my Eastern European friends, I hear you too - and that Xenophobia is just as wrong, and I want that to change too but right now Black people are dying needlessly.
Right now, rather than supporting the Black community which is so dearly suffering, so many of you are choosing instead to rant on an anonymous platform - and getting mad at us for speaking back. I donâ€™t owe you anything, neither do our other admin. This is our page, we arenâ€™t funded, if you donâ€™t like it you can go and set up your page - we wonâ€™t tolerate it. This is a time for the community to come together, to recognise how each of us inhabit a space but that other people want to be safe in their spaces too - is it so wrong to fight for that?
You can use statistics, but you canâ€™t change that fear of ending up dead while innocent. You can love hip hop and the Harlem Renaissance, read books by Malorie Blackman, but canâ€™t even NOT question what your Black friends go through?
Having a platform is always about trying to keep a safe space for the UCL community - but for our Black friends and family (alongside other POC) it isnâ€™t right now. Do you see how many tears you're causing behind a computer screen? How you too are contributing to making people feel unsafe at UCL? Are you happy? Does it make you feel good to be angry? Does it feel like you have control?
UCL i love you, but learn to do better.
Until then, why tolerate ignorance?
Sincerely, the people you have called:
- Terrorists
- Freedom of speech-banning Nazis
- Angry feminists
- Left-wing
- Right-wing
- biased against people of colour
- biased towards people of colour
- Racist
- Dictators
Ways you can support the Black Lives Matter movement and the Uyghur community:
https://blacklivesmatters.carrd.co
https://uhrp.org/what-you-can-do
UHRP.ORG
WHAT YOU CAN DO

I know people have been talking about RUMSBC and their lack of diversity and I do agree they need to work on their image. Theyâ€™re talked about a lot in a negative way by other clubs for a reason. However I think another club that needs to address a sense of elitism is RUMSHC both menâ€™s and womenâ€™s. Whilst these clubs are more ethnically diverse it is true that a lot of the members have come from private schools and so there is a social class barrier. I think this comes across during drinking events and the expensive prices. I think a lot of clubs, but especially HC and BC have expensive membership and kit prices and this does create a class barrier. It may not be the intention but it does have its consequences. Whilst rowing may be considered an elitist sport anyway, having to pay something like Â£60/80 for membership followed by a lot more for all the dinners and unisuits is going to set limitations for a lot of people. The same can be said for hockey but perhaps to slightly less of a degree. Itâ€™s sad because being part of these clubs can create a huge sense of community but I think in previous years the community had been curated by who can afford it.
I think this is less of a case for clubs like RUMSFC, RUMS Netball, tennis etc who are all ethnically and socially diverse. I think itâ€™s just worth pointing out that even though HC and BC are two of the biggest clubs, you would think they would be more accessible.

text:
#UCLove70999
Some people really need to pull their heads out of their asses. It makes me sick that you can blatantly disregard all of the hard work people put into a project, a production, or a show, and not credit them for it. I've watched this happen all of this year, and I'm so sick of it. Power-hungry bunch of backstabbing snakes. And the fact that you have the audacity to twist the truth to fit your narrative and your opinion of the world is just appaling. I don't care if you're a committee member, or a contributor, or a cast member, for all I care, you can be the fucking Pope, it doesn't give you the right to abuse the power you've been given to suit your own selfish needs. You deny and omit the contributions of so many people that have worked so hard on these events and projects, and for what!? Your own personal satisfaction? So that you can be perceived as "the top of the food chain?" What gives you the right to screw with people's lives like this?
Yes, this is very much aimed at particular people in a particular society, although I'm sure it happens in other societies and departments/research groups as well.

text:
#UCLove70996
I wrote #UCLove70823, the post about white privilege. I am glad that a lot of people read it and liked it. I originally planned to only write one post, almost as a vent towards some UCLove posts and comments I had seen. However after reading some of the comments on my post and other recent UCLove posts I felt the need to respond to further elaborate one some of the stuff I had written.
Firstly, one of the most common points made recently is how white privilege applies to Eastern European and Slavic countries. As a person who has not lived there nor particularly learnt about the history in that region, I'm not going to pretend to know the struggles they go through. However, I will reiterate a point I made in my original post. No one has ever said that all white people have an easy life. That is not what white privilege means. It does not mean you are by definition always privileged. What it means more than anything, is that you are MORE privileged than a minority in the same conditions as you. So in the context of the Eastern European/Slavic/Balkan countries, it means if you are a white person from that region and you have a neighbour who is black, you and your neighbour would experience the same discrimination, but your neighbour will experience even more discrimination because of their skin colour. This discrimination may be from locals from that country (let's not pretend that there's no racism in Eastern European countries btw). This discrimination may be from other people. Wherever you and your neighbour go, you neighbour has a higher chance to be discriminated because of their skin colour.
Once again, white privilege isn't about how if you are white you are instantly going to be rich, have a great discrimination-free life and die peacefully. It means that compared to POC, who is in a similar social, political and economic situation as a white person, they will be disadvantaged compared to you. Quite simply, if you recognise there is racism, then you should acknowledge white privilege. A part of white privilege is the fact that you are much less likely to experience discriminate because of your skin colour.
Secondly, there is no shame in having white privilege. No one is shaming you for having white privileges. What people are shaming you for is your ignorance. Some of you deny your white privilege, some of you don't even try to learn and read about racial issues, some of you only acknowledge you privilege and then stop there. What you should do is learn. Listen to what people have to say. There is so much on the internet about all of this. Read it. Educate yourself. Then you should use your privilege. Use your privilege to speak out. Go protest, go educate your friends and family, go stand up for people of colour. There are so many times that POCs have to stand up for themselves in front of an audience which is primarily ignorant. Personally, I have been in situations where people have asked me if saying _____ was racist. What they said would make me highly uncomfortable, but because there was no one to back me up and because I was afraid to be ridiculed or mocked for not being able to take a joke or for being easily "triggered", I had to say it wasn't. Similarly there are times where I am trying to explain things to my friends and they dismiss what I say because they think I'm overreacting or I'm over-sensitive. As a minority, we will often find ourselves in a situation where we are talking to an audience (whether it be friends or strangers) that is a white majority. We will often find that no matter what we say, it falls on deaf ears. We are called snowflakes or angry, we are dismissed, we are laughed out. What you can do with your white privilege is help to prevent this.
Lastly, in response to the first comment on my original post. Where a non-white, first generation, state school attending immigrant shares their views on this. Whether they meant it or not, their comment was incredibly dismissive of what I had written. Their comment to me seemed like they were saying because they did not have any issues, white privilege doesn't exist. Well as a non-white, first generation, public school attending immigrant myself, I was bullied. I was bullied verbally and physically. Everyday for 7 years, I was not allowed to forget that I wasn't white and that I didn't belong. I was scared everyday to do the simplest of things. I practically grew up here, I attended primary school and one year of secondary school in the UK before I finally decided I didn't want to be bullied everyday anymore. I begged my parents to let me go back to Hong Kong.
Even now my parents are scared for me to return to London in September. After Covid-19, they think that racism towards people who look Chinese will be much worse than before. They remind me about Jonathan Mok, who was the Singaporean student who got beat up on Oxford Street at the start of the Coronavirus. I wish I could convince them that I'll be safe but I'm not 100% sure of that myself.
I have not included all the specifics of what happened to me and how I was bullied. But the fact that I feel the need to prove to anyone that racism exists is fucked up. White privilege is literally defined as the fact that white people have a social advantage that POCs in the same social, economical and political do not have. If there is racism, there is white privilege.
If you ask me if I'm privileged or not, I would say yes I am. Compared to some people in this world, I am incredibly privileged. I have shelter, food and clothes. I'm at one of the best universities in the world. I am happy to be where I am. But my journey has been so much harder than if I was white. That is what white privilege is.

#UCLove70973
As a Chinese, I just feel a bit low when I get back home. When I bring up a political issue in a family/friends discussion, very often I make the people I love feel uncomfortable. And I can understand it, it's normal. There's this ghost of censorship that haunts us- in most cases it doesn't get you, but you know it could. And that's sad.
Also, I wouldn't be surprised if some people in China confuse government with people, due to a lack of (or perhaps excessive) education. That's why a lot of people laugh at us, but I really think they're the victims too. It's a clever trick.
Sorry if this is not related here smh. I just feel depressed about the future and it's beyond my power. Freedom is not all roses and no thorns, but being mute is never the best option.

text:
#UCLove70972
Honest question here, just trying to understand the complex matter of destroying statues, renaming street names etc.
In the case of statues depicting racist people, why can't we simply displace them to museums instead of straight up destroying them? Can't we archive what will be seen as interesting historical artifacts in the future, without plainly destroying them? Museums can always indicate what these people did and how bad their actions were with regards to specific groups of people, but I believe it would still be interesting to keep these as a memory of the racist mentality of some influential people in the context of their era, and show the role they played in destroying so many lives.
What would the argument be to simply destroy a historical artifact, as controversial as it is, instead of keeping it as a memory of a horrible past in a museum where it belongs?
Moreover, with concerning street names and notable city places, not only with regards to racist people but every time a city replaces a name with another, wouldn't it be justified to indicate the past name(s) of such a place underneath the plaque or whatever? Straight up renaming such things whilst forcing the forgetfulness of people can lead to dangerous paths like trying to rewrite history in order to influence the memory that we have of such eras.
I hope this will create interesting and constructive discussions, and will help me understand such a debate a bit more. Thanks :)

RUMSBC's anti-racism statement is a step in the right direction but more needs to be done. Let's be honest, boat club is probably the whitest society in the med school, so why are only members getting surveyed about these issues? We should open it to all medical students, especially since there are so many BME medics who don't join and even those who do join often drop out again. I don't think we can get a true assessment of the situation and the factors which keep the club white and privileged by looking at the club from the inside only and keeping the discussion to our (predominantly white and privileged) members.

A reply to the following comment (that I will not post publicly because I try to keep my social media apolitical. Sorry!)
'Doesnt the fact that people are now able to protest because of the pandemic and its effect on jobs say more about the role capitalism plays in suppressing grassroots movements than about those people's genuine desire to participate in the movement? Jobs arent always about 'financial gain', for a lot of us they're about survival'
Two questions
â€¢ Can people not protest on weekends in capitalist societies? When they're not working? And if they value a few free weekends more than the cause.. then do they care THAT much about the cause?
â€¢ In a society different to our current capitalism (one which is hard to define as I acknowledge there are many variants) surely people would still need to work? People wouldn't just be able to take the weeks off work to protest all the time?
Anyway sorry. I will leave that there. Appreciate the response. Unfortunately I want to keep my Facebook feed apolitical.

text:
#UCLove70957
Because there have been so many negative experiences with BAME students feeling kinda left out from societies, I'd like to share my positive experiences too I guess just to show there are good societies too.
I'm Chinese, and I've joined two sports societies (it seems sports socs are really the issue atm idk), and I've just finished my second year. (Not gonna say which ones they are because you'd really easily be able to tell who I am, unless people really want me to reveal all). One of them is a very diverse society, with loads of white, asian, east asian, whatever you name it students. There's also loads of LGBT peeps as well, and I've made lots of really good friends there. The social side of this society is fabulous.
The second society is a UOL one and it's my main competitive sporting society. It's a sport more traditionally known for being a lot whiter. In my first year, whenever I went to any competitions around the UK there would only ever be two non-white students - me and an HK guy from Imperial. And that's if Imperial even decided to go to that event. Despite this though, I never felt outcast when in London due to my race or anything like that. It does help though that actually even though everyone else was white, there were loads of international students which helped with diversity. I managed to make my way onto committee this year and next year, and I never felt that I had to work extra hard for that position or anything, I just so happened to be most qualified for that position.
I guess what I'm saying is there is always hope about finding a wholesome, inclusive society, but you probably already knew that. It's just a case of getting lucky and finding something that's right for you. Should you have to get lucky to find a good soc? No, every society should be as welcoming as possible but please remember these societies are run by 18-21 year olds, barely adults and they are trying their best I promise.
Either way, that's just my experience. Take what you want from it. I just hope that everyone can find something right for them as easily as I did.

text:
#UCLove70944
Am I a racist?
If i am walking home alone in camden at night and I see a group of people on a street corner I unconsciously have a prejudice against them based on the colour of their skin. If that group were black I would be more inclined to cross the road to avoid them than if they were Asian or white. Other factors take precident over the skin colour such as how they act and what clothing they are wearing ect. But this scenario assumes they are wearing the same clothes and acting the same.
(I see similarilites in the way a woman might be more inclined to cross the road if the person on the corner was a man a opposed to a woman, it's a the body's natural instinct to avoid danger)
For some context I have been attacked once and attempted to be mugged on three other occasions whilst at UCL. Only one out of the approx 10 people involved in all of these incidents was white, the remaining 9 were black (even though 1/8 in london are black).
I ask this question, am I a racist? because alot of white people are posting on social media currently with support for the cause, however I believe many of my friends and people I know would do the same thing given the circumstances. After all our body is trying to stay alive and using everything its learnt subconsciously to avoid danger. I believe the solution to these prejudices is education and equal opportunities for all to avoid a situation. I have never insulted anyone based on the colour of their skin or treated my friends differently based on this, I believe its turning the prejudices into actions that directly affect the person to be racist. But on the other hand, someone crossing the road based on the colour of my skin would affect me!
I find it hard to talk to my nonce white friends about this as I dont want to cause them harm, the tone of lots of instagram stories ect prevent this kind of dialogue.
I would like to know your thoughts, am I a racist? would you do the same?

text:
#UCLove70942
I originally wanted to reply to a post but can't find it now - a person from an ethnic minority saying that they have been at UCL all year and UCL is not racist. As someone who has been at UCL for 5+ years - I can assure you it is.
Take a look at sports teams and their diversity. How many BAME students do you think join sports like rowing, hockey, athletics? The answer is not a lot. These teams do nothing to change that, and as someone who has tried to join those teams, I have been left out because I wasn't white and didn't go to an elite private school in Kent. Their sports night chants even incorporate 'zulu warriors' to get a pint down.
Take a look at their curriculum, especially for history. Does it paint an accurate picture of British history and colonisation? The answer is no. That is why students have launched a 'decolonise the curriculum' campaign.
Take a look at their incoming students, especially for medicine. I can assure you that black students are a rarity in UCL medical school. They are also more likely to fail practical exams (OSCE's). Finally, in medical school, there is no condition taught with regards to black skin (except jaundice lol). Every picture we have learned from has white skin because that is the default right? There is a petition to improve representation of skin conditions in the curriculum.
UCL is not innocent. The stories of out right racism are few in number sure. Institutional racism and bias is a lot harder to see and appreciate. And that is where UCL can improve.

In the light of Pride Month, Hindu philosophy provides a unique perspective on the LGBTQ+ community. We identify with our body and mind but according to the Upanishads, this is not who we are. They teach us that while the body and mind form our apparent identity, our essential identity is the Self, consciousness that is free from identity and witnesses all. They propose that the Ä€tman (the Self) - the unchanging aspect of an individual - inhabits the bodies of all beings. The Ä€tman is beyond the notions of gender and sexuality. These aspects are of the body and the mind. The theory of reincarnation offers an explanation to the emergence of a variety of genders and sexual preferences. From one life to the next, one acquires inclinations, desires and characteristics that can be expressed in future lives. As a result, individuals across the spectrums of gender and sexuality are seen in society.

We need to stop looking to politics to bring about any change for black people in the US and UK, it is not a matter of right and left.
Can't help but get triggered when people use BLM as a way to support labour or conservatives - lacks any balance and lacks any historical support that change will happen.
Do not feed into the current "culture war" that people like Trump but also the socialist governments are perpetuating.
The leftâ€™s stance towards the Black Lives Matter resurgence is that dignified peaceful protests must be encouraged, but there should be no extremist destructive excesses and looting. In some elementary sense that is right, of course, but it misses the true meaning of violent excess: a reaction to the fact that liberal, peaceful and gradual political change has not worked and systemic racism persists in the US.
What emerges in violent protest is an anger that cannot be adequately represented in our political space.
This is also why so many representatives of the establishment, not only liberals but also conservatives, are openly critical of Trumpâ€™s aggressive stance towards the protesters. The establishment desperately wants to channel protests into the coordinates of the eternal â€œstruggle against racismâ€, one of liberalismâ€™s endless tasks.
They are ready to admit that we didnâ€™t do enough, that there is a long and difficult work ahead, just to prevent a quick radicalization of the protests, not towards even more violence but their transformation into an autonomous political movement with a platform clearly demarcated from the liberal establishment.
Violent protests are the return of the repressed of our liberal societies; a symptom which enacts what cannot be formulated in the vocabulary of liberal multiculturalism.
Usually, we accuse people of just speaking, instead of doing something. These protests are the exact opposite: people act violently because they donâ€™t have the words to express their grievance within our political structure.
Violence is awful but we must acknowledge why people are acting this way first. We must find an equally impactful but peaceful way to show discontent for the current establishment through which systematic racism takes place, then start over again with a new one.

text:
#UCLove70895
I'm a disabled gay woman and I have faced my fair share of discrimination on that front, but you know what? I still have white priveledge and have massively benefitted from it. You can be oppressed and still have white priveledge. The fact is I'm never going to face discrimination over the colour of my skin. When I make applications for further education or internships etc I am often worried about being turned down or overlooked because of the accommodations I need but I am never worried that someone will throw aside my cv as soon as they read my name.
In terms of intersectionality, on a case by case basis I'm sure you can find examples where one black person is more priveledged than a white person. But that is not the point! It's about aggregate, its about an entire population! If we just focus on ableism for a sec, so many conditions are underdiagnosed in black people and other poc and their concerns are ignored by healthcare professionals. The finding that the disproportionate effect of covid on BAME is down to socioeconomic factors rather than genetics isnt proof that racism dowsnt exist, its proof that BAME are disproportionately represented in lower income deciles. And unless you wanna believe that BAME are on average less productive or skilled or whatever than whites (which is, you know, racist) than you have to accept that this means they face disadvantages in terms of education and employment. My private school was overwhelmingly white, as are many, and private school educated children are over represented in university ranks (and in government and boardrooms). So you could argue I'm privileged because I went to a private school (which of course I am) but why did I go? Because my parents could afford it - whilst i should imagine unconscious bias and perhaps even outright discrimination plays a part in my school's acceptance rates, it cant explain the entirety of the under representation.
The way I see it, my whiteness isnt something to be guilty about- that helps no one. But it is my responsibility to recognise where I am advantaged unfairly and to educate myself on the issues. It is my responsibility to make sure I dont perpetuate stereotypes and to challenge my inner unconscious bias (because we all have it). You know what it's not even that hard! Just listen to your BAME peers, dont dismiss their struggles because you personally havent seen racism and therefore it cant be real, do what you can to helpn, be that donating to causes if you can afford to, signing petitions, writing to your MP, or more personally, standing up and calling out racism when you see it. If your friend makes a racist joke (or an ableist, homophobic, sexist etc. Joke for that matter) call them out on it. If your classmate feels alienated by studying in a building named after a eugenicist, let UCL know that it isnt right. If you need any more ideas, do some googling.
My last word on the matter: this isnt the oppression Olympics! Maybe some people have it worse but right now the fight is Black Lives Matter!
Happy pride, I have my rights thanks to black trans women.

These issues donâ€™t seem to be so prevalent in ethnically and culturally homogenous countries. You donâ€™t see any innocent men killed by racist police in Japan. You donâ€™t hear of many Neo-fascist hate groups in South Korea, or Argentina. Are multiracial western societies doomed to a future of racial oppression and hatred? Was large scale immigration a mistake? Iâ€™d be interested to hear what people think about this.

text:
#UCLove70893
I've seen the pain and divide making the rounds in those difficult times and I hope that every person who is in pain due to oppression, prejudice, lockdown or loneliness finds a bit of solace. But I felt the need to reach out to this community for help and advice.
I have been trying to educate myself and contribute as much as I can to the causes in the recent times. However, I am struggling with massive guilt due to the pain and divide currently in the world. I am looking at the privilege I've had in life and while I've suffered from people being prejudiced against me I cannot imagine the pain minorities face in the world. I admire the strength and passion of all people fighting and standing against prejudice in these times. However, I cannot help but feeling like I'm a bad human being for not being more involved, for not doing more to ease the pain I see and I feel guilty in my own skin.
I suffer from diagnosed social anxiety and I have my support group and friends. But this does affect how I interact with the world. I don't post online, I can't go to mass gatherings and I can't do much but offer one on one support.
So I want to ask those people that are in pain, what could someone like me do to help you ? What do you need and what makes you feel listened to and supported ?

text:
#UCLove70890
When artefacts of the past: statues, films, place names etc. make us feel uncomfortable, it is natural to want to remove them from our modern society. Yet while individuals like Edward Colston are indefensibly linked with slavery and few will regret his statueâ€™s removal, doing so sets a dangerous precedent for how the past is to be treated.
Thousands of British historical artefacts are to differing extents tied not just to slavery but to a multitude of other practices that are considered wrong when judged against modern values and standards. Removing all these traces of the past is not just impractical but damaging to our cultural heritage.
Therefore, instead of seeking to erase the aspects of our history we find troubling, the focus should instead be on changing the understanding of historical monuments so that they are no longer celebrations of racist individuals and practices but timely reminders of the uncomfortable aspects of the past that we are still striving to escape.

text:
#UCLove70872
This is a reply to the person who commented on #UCLove70823 with their own experience as a non-white person in the UK. I want to start by saying thank you for sharing your own personal experience - I appreciate that. However, although you may not have faced any particular overt racism yourself, I want to discuss some other aspects.
Firstly, not all racism is â€˜overtâ€™. For anyone living in a racialized society, systematic racism can be both conscious and subconscious. For example, if you have an African or Asian sounding surname, statistics show that you need to send out about twice as many job applications as those with a traditionally English sounding surname, just to get an interview. An interviewer may not be consciously aware of how they treat such names, but it still happensâ€¦ this is still systematic racism.
Secondly, there are so many examples to demonstrate the ongoing mistreatment of BME people. The majority of the victims of the Grenfell incident were BME. They were living there because of the systematic racism in our society (i.e. are given lower paid jobs and so live in relatively poorer areas etc.). Then, because of the colour of their skin, they received little justice and support. Furthermore, the fact that white people have actively made fake posts about the recent BLM protests shows ongoing racism in this society. I have seen photos of white police officers with multiple injuries with captions like â€˜this was done by black BLM protestersâ€¦ white lives matter!â€™ when actually, that photo was taken during EDL protests in 2018 (i.e. those injuries were inflicted by another white person). I can go on and onâ€¦ what about the lack of education about the oppression of black people in schools? Personally, I had only just found out about Churchillâ€™s violently racist outlook (and the causing of a huge genocide in Bengali). Whilst I still look up to all those brave people who fought in that war (and I always will be so thankful), it is hypocritical to not be taught about the Bengali concentration camps that Churchill himself set up. What about the the tragic death of the Somali schoolgirl Shukri Abdi? Her death was ruled as suicide, despite allegations that â€œanother child forced her to get into the water and later â€˜laughed for two minutes while she died" because she couldnâ€™t swim.
Regarding my own experiences, my uncle told me the other day that black people are at fault because â€˜black on black is the worst crime and white people killing black people doesn't matterâ€™. My white aunt even used the N word in front of me the other day, and she has been educated at university! I can go onâ€¦ my black colleague received multiple messages after the BLM protests, calling her a â€˜dirty monkeyâ€™. There are smaller, more subtler cases of racism that I have witnessed myself. When I was in sixth form, one of my black friends was told by a white guy in our school that â€œyou look good for a black girlâ€.
We cannot deny that racism does not exist in the UK. It goes on everyday - sometimes it is so normalised and subconscious that it just goes undetected. Yes, the racism experienced here may be different than the police brutality in the US (for instance, gun laws are different here), but UK prisons are currently holding a larger proportion of BME youths than America.
Also, Iâ€™d like to point out that as a white person, I do not feel personal guilt for the actions of my ancestors, but what I do feel guilty for is not having previously made the effort to stand up to racism that I see everyday and to have not previously made a huge effort to learn about the BLM movement and white privilege etc. I also do not think that discussions on here about white privilege is not telling BME students â€œhow poor and oppressed they areâ€, but it is rather raising awareness about what white privilege is and that it exists. Discussions like this are needed if change is going to happen.
Thanks for reading!

I think a large part of the misunderstanding in these white privilege arguments stems from the terminology. Nobody is claiming that white people have good/great lives. Economic, social, mental etc. struggles are universal regardless of skin colour, and people who argue about the existence of white privilege aren't denying that.
What they're describing is more of a "POC tax" where POC will have more struggles to face due to race. It's less the case of white people living privileged lives, and more of POC being underprivileged, if you will.
Personally, I also don't think the term white privilege captures the essence of the issue; it shouldn't be considered a privilege to not be mistreated over race. In a perfect world, all people would be treated at least as fairly as white people are today, if not more so. Not to mention the needless debate it causes when people point out that most white people also don't live lives which would be considered privileged.
But that's just my two cents ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸

text:
#UCLove70854
Some thoughts on why a lot of the talk about white "privilege" is problematic...
To me, it is horrific to call a "privilege" such basic things as human rights, being treated decently by the state and its law enforcement. This is not and should not be treated as a privilege - this is the bare minimum.
And what is even more problematic is the kind of rhetoric of trying to enforce guilt on people for... having basic human rights, much like you would shame a rich 16-year-old child showing off the super expensive car his father got him. It is repugnant that the one situation of privilege-induced shame should be comparable to the other.
What instead we should talk about is about how minority communities and especially black communities are disadvantaged and are being denied these basic rights. Now, I am already reading the comments where people would tell me this is not what white privilege means etc and that white people are "comparably privileged".
However, language is a powerful tool and language has meaning within it and leaves strong impressions often subliminal ones. When we want to make a big debate and movement the words we use matter and should be chosen carefully, as the movement and the principles that it advocates are compromised by this rhetoric- not only because it alienates certain parts of the population from wanting to listen but because it is simply wrong and harmful to connotate "not being beaten up by the police" with "privilege".
When you talk about "privilege" it implies something additional, a "rare advantage". However, the things people are talking about should be the basic position.
Shaming people for being so "lucky" and "privileged" because they have basic rights and are treated with basic human dignity and not discriminated against undermines these values that you are trying to promote. Please start talking about a much needed "restoration of minorities basic rights".
Being treated humanely and to not be discriminated against should never be treated as a "privilege"

text:
#UCLove70834
To all future second year students:
I have just finished my first year and I would say I have enjoyed term one. I must say I met some really nice and fun friends at UCL, but because of the prolongued strike and the coronavirus outbreak I just feel as if I didn't spend enough time with them. We were 'close' and still are, but after so much time apart we missed opportunities to talk about next year, how to organize ourseves and most importantly... HOUSING. I am tempted to go back to London as I love the city and I enjoyed my friends laughs and going out etc. But part of the reason why I feel insecure about it is that I don't feel like asking any of my friends to move in together. First, I don't know if we are actually compatible as flatmates.. and I am scared that they might have already arranged housing with someone else. I know we are the only year in generations that has been affected this way.. but I am sure there must be other people feeling like this going into second year. I can't be the only one who feels like they missed on so much this year for strike & coronavirus... So here's a call to anyone who finds themselves in this situation. Feel free to like the post and we could maybe get in touch, hoping many of us will find other known friends, maybe coursemates, who are looking for the precisely the same thing but they just haven't talked to each other.

text:
#UCLove70828
can we all just commit to being civil, respectable, and academic human beings who are looking towards a rational and reasonable solution?
i love my generation. we have all grown up into a world with a shifting global order (two global wars and countless skirmishes!), the looming threat of climate change, an unparalleled age of technological growth whose impact on human behaviour and depression has not been correctly measured, as well as clearly revealed racial/class-based disparities. our moment on the planet comes at a particularly special time, and the fact that we have voices and can truly voice our opinions is great, and in fact is what defines our species.
buttttttt, another equally harsh reality that we have to face is that we do not always have all the information, and that for us to truly urge the change we want to see in the world, we must first understand it. consistently on this forum and others like instagram, i've seen people becoming indignant when others don't agree with them, as well as positively unrepentant about their sweeping suggestions for reform or the maintenance of the status quo.
can we all take a second to look back, stop, and actually do some strong research on what the "other side" is saying? can we take a moment to understand that issues like racial and class based discrimination have existed for hundreds of years, and that to fix them will take time and effort? and, can we agree to stop completely discrediting concepts of privilege and inequality? or at the bare minimum, can we, for one second, not immediately assume that anyone that disagrees with us is doing so out of malice? that their perspective as a fellow human being perhaps has a place? that perhaps even if what they are saying is not "right" in our eyes, that we can still attempt to hear them and understand why they think this way?
i know this all sounds like sappy bullcrap, but we are all here a very brief time. if we spend our time outraged at each other, and blocking out communications without taking the time to empathise, we will completely waste our experience. as scholars, we must confront our biases, question our realities, and ultimately work hard to construct the next generation. it is a complete fallacy to think we can achieve this last step with only a quarter or half of us - we need everyone, from different places, ethnicities, races, and creeds - on board.
i know this is especially hard to do when members of your own community are being slaughtered, when you feel the burning intensity of oppression...but if you are to make any true lasting movement, you must realise that all stakeholders in society must also have a place in it.

I'm enjoying lockdown and I don't want it to end. Yes, I feel guilty about this and recognise my privilege. I know some people are unwell, have financial difficulty, mental health issues, and are even dying. But I'm really enjoying the opportunity to focus my coursework essays, watch netflix, bake cakes, read a book etc. without FOMO. I'm dreading returning back to "normal". I don't want to have desk exams or buy overpriced food at pret or be dragged to a club just to take photos for my friend's instagram.
The weird thing is I considered myself an extrovert before all this but now I'm realising that being alone with barely any responsibilities can be very peaceful.

text:
#UCLove70814
That little addendum the admins added to that (actually quite reasonable) post about "white privilege" was unnecessary to be honest.
I would add a couple of points.
If you define privilege along a racial axis, you are required to define privilege along an infinite number of other axes, not limited to race, gender, sexual orientation and class, but also more obscure things like height and perceived physical attractiveness. Hence arises the notion of intersectionality. The more variables you add, the smaller the impact of the racial axis on an individual's privilege. Only when all other scales of privilege are exactly equal between two people does the idea of "white privilege" have the potential to become at all useful on an individual level. If it is not useful on an individual level, what can the idea be said to achieve? After all, as we are constantly reminded, change begins with individuals. There is a reason why people often find this concept unintuitive and inaccessible, and they should not be thought of as uneducated for feeling this way.
In addition, the data is not clear-cut. On the one hand, you have employers generally being more likely to invite a candidate for interview if they have a white name, all other things being equal. Then you have household earnings, where white British families trail Indian, Chinese and mixed ethnicity families. "Other white" ethnic groups also trail "other Asian" groups by the same measure. White British children are also the least likely group to attend higher education. Your average white British working-class teenager who is severely held back by his socioeconomic status is probably not thinking "well, at least I'm not held back by my skin colour". How are you going to get him to join your cause?
Then there are the sources that the admins added to their post. It is now common knowledge that BAME people suffer disproportionate consequences from coronavirus. I looked through the sources you added to illustrate this point, and the majority of the content was explanations about confounding factors that may contribute to this, for example socioeconomic status, roles within the healthcare system, and housing situation. Active discrimination on the part of hospitals seems to be accounted for principally by anecdotes. Of course, this is a type of evidence, but I wouldn't say it is strong enough to draw any conclusions from at the current time. More research is needed to identify gaps that aren't accounted for by confounding factors.
You link a source claiming that black Americans are killed by police at a rate disproportionate to their population. This is true, however this is the wrong denominator. It makes more sense to look at the likelihood of being killed by police when controlling for the number of police interactions. Turns out, when this is done, the data is again less clear https://scholar.harvard.edu/fryer/publications/reconciling-results-racial-differences-police-shootings. Of course, this doesn't rule out the fact that black people are disproportionately "policed", but it goes against the killing narrative. Similarly in the UK, black people who are arrested are no more likely to die in custody than white people who are arrested https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/52890363
I await this post receiving a lot of angry/laugh reacts but I thought I'd try and introduce a bit of balance to what is largely a group of people making their first foray into identity politics.
A lot of the time when people urge others to "educate themselves" on these issues, what they are really asking is for them to educate themselves on the viewpoints of a specific author, group of authors, or a specific sociological school of thought. I'd be interested to know if the same people have ever read anything arguing against the concept, or at least the usefulness, of "white privilege". The same arguments surrounding the term have been in the mainstream for at least the last 5 years, yet have made relatively little progress in terms of getting people on-board outside academic circles and Twitter. Talk about vapid contrarianism. Ask yourself why that is.
post_text:
#UCLove70814
That little addendum the admins added to that (actually quite reasonable) post about "white privilege" was unnecessary to be honest.
I would add a couple of points.
If you define privilege along a racial axis, you are required to define privilege along an infinite number of other axes, not limited to race, gender, sexual orientation and class, but also more obscure things like height and perceived physical attractiveness. Hence arises the notion of intersectionality. The more variables you add, the smaller the impact of the racial axis on an individual's privilege. Only when all other scales of privilege are exactly equal between two people does the idea of "white privilege" have the potential to become at all useful on an individual level. If it is not useful on an individual level, what can the idea be said to achieve? After all, as we are constantly reminded, change begins with individuals. There is a reason why people often find this concept unintuitive and inaccessible, and they should not be thought of as uneducated for feeling this way.
In addition, the data is not clear-cut. On the one hand, you have employers generally being more likely to invite a candidate for interview if they have a white name, all other things being equal. Then you have household earnings, where white British families trail Indian, Chinese and mixed ethnicity families. "Other white" ethnic groups also trail "other Asian" groups by the same measure. White British children are also the least likely group to attend higher education. Your average white British working-class teenager who is severely held back by his socioeconomic status is probably not thinking "well, at least I'm not held back by my skin colour". How are you going to get him to join your cause?
Then there are the sources that the admins added to their post. It is now common knowledge that BAME people suffer disproportionate consequences from coronavirus. I looked through the sources you added to illustrate this point, and the majority of the content was explanations about confounding factors that may contribute to this, for example socioeconomic status, roles within the healthcare system, and housing situation. Active discrimination on the part of hospitals seems to be accounted for principally by anecdotes. Of course, this is a type of evidence, but I wouldn't say it is strong enough to draw any conclusions from at the current time. More research is needed to identify gaps that aren't accounted for by confounding factors.
You link a source claiming that black Americans are killed by police at a rate disproportionate to their population. This is true, however this is the wrong denominator. It makes more sense to look at the likelihood of being killed by police when controlling for the number of police interactions. Turns out, when this is done, the data is again less clear https://scholar.harvard.edu/fryer/publications/reconciling-results-racial-differences-police-shootings. Of course, this doesn't rule out the fact that black people are disproportionately "policed", but it goes against the killing narrative. Similarly in the UK, black people who are arrested are no more likely to die in custody than white people who are arrested https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/52890363
I await this post receiving a lot of angry/laugh reacts but I thought I'd try and introduce a bit of balance to what is largely a group of people making their first foray into identity politics.
A lot of the time when people urge others to "educate themselves" on these issues, what they are really asking is for them to educate themselves on the viewpoints of a specific author, group of authors, or a specific sociological school of thought. I'd be interested to know if the same people have ever read anything arguing against the concept, or at least the usefulness, of "white privilege". The same arguments surrounding the term have been in the mainstream for at least the last 5 years, yet have made relatively little progress in terms of getting people on-board outside academic circles and Twitter. Talk about vapid contrarianism. Ask yourself why that is.

I would just like to point out that the "white privilege" rhetoric I've seen splattered across social media platforms is so counterproductive . Think of the millions of white people living in extreme poverty across the west, those who have lost their job due to Covid-19, the homeless, the disabled, the terminally ill, those living in highly dysfunctional families, whose life is a complete mess and an utter tragedy, how do you think they feel when a wealthy kid with a phd from their top university bubble insist they should feel guilty about being born with white skin and how much more advantaged they are than non-white people? Being white has a variety of advantages, fact, but it's not as determinant to leading a good life as much as social class. Being born white doesn't automatically place you in a good social class, likewise being born non-white doesn't automatically place you in a bad social class. The simplistic view according to which all white people are so privileged and anyone else is oppressed is terribly divisive. The phrase I've seen repeated everywhere to counteract this argument is this one: "I'm not saying white people don't have problems or that their problems are not important, i'm saying that the colour of their skin is not one of these problems," which is the same as saying "white people have problems, even very serious ones, but none of these problems is as bad as being non-white" which is simply not true. This statement creates the paradox that white people's problems are less important than non-white people's problems - therefore effectively turning white skin into a problem itself, in fact if it wasn't problematic being white why would you make such a big deal out of it? Being white is clearly a problem to you. Making a problem out of white skin won't help solve problems of people with non-white skin, actually it may end up making things just worse. Don't be surprised when all these unacknowledged white people you are ridiculing end up voting for Donald Trump, Boris Johnson, Bolsonaro, Salvini etc. What about we start actually collaborating and empathizing with each other, focusing on the interests and goals we ALL have in common such as eradicating violence, redistributing wealth, improving education and healthcare, demilitarizing the police (PS resentment towards white people is not a very good mutual interest) WITHOUT turning everything into a racial football match? I'm confident many whites and non-whites would agree. Peace x

Don't be surprised when all these unacknowledged white people you are ridiculing end up voting for Donald Trump, Boris Johnson, Bolsonaro, Salvini etc. What about we start actually collaborating and empathizing with each other, focusing on the interests and goals we ALL have in common such as eradicating violence, redistributing wealth, improving education and healthcare, demilitarizing the police (PS resentment towards white people is not a very good mutual interest) WITHOUT turning everything into a racial football match? I'm confident many whites and non-whites would agree. Peace x
Admin: oh the strawman in this argument. The statement you quoted ("I'm not saying white people don't have problems or that their problems are not important, i'm saying that the colour of their skin is not one of these problems,") has nothing to do with your 'explanation' ('which is the same as saying "white people have problems, even very serious ones, but none of these problems is as bad as being non-white"). #UCLove70777
While the Not Cool Club has done some impressive work over the last year in raising awareness about sexual harassment on campus, its mission to promote diversity and BAME inclusion will be hindered by its refusal to acknowledge how the club itself hijacked a movement that was put into motion by black women.
The club's website cites the #MeToo movement as its inspiration, but nowhere does it credit Tarana Burke and the other incredible black women who laboured and persevered to ensure that the voices of black victims of sexual violence were heard. The Not Cool Club took this movement and framed it through its own lens which, consciously or not, is white centric. It white washes the efforts of the black women behind #MeToo and is problematic in this way, particularly as its committee lacks so much diversity and is not representative of the multiethnic make-up of our campus.
Yes, it is now making steps to become more diverse - but acknowledge your own problematic beginnings whilst doing so as well. Challenge your own manifest white-centricity. Give credit to black creators and black women where it is due. For further info on this, read these following articles:
qz.com: 'MeToo hijacked black womenâ€™s work on race and gender equality'
medium.com: 'The White Washing of #MeToo'
By the way, I tried to publish a UCLove saying the same exact things a few months ago but it was never approved. I hope the revival of BLM has allowed admins to review their own biases and will allow this post to go through as it should have last time. Our voices and criticisms should NOT be silenced, not least by a confessions page of an ethnically diverse university.

This is a sad day at UCL. I am devastated and heartbroken because the best university I worked at for 30 years, is now the 10th best university in the world. We were on the 8th place last year.
It is time to think why we are falling behind. It is now time to think what do we need to do to take the lead. It is now time to plan the next 100 years with novelty, vision and changes that can shape the world we live in. UCL Engineering faculty slogan is "UCL Engineering, change the world" I think we should not settle with less that that.
As I wrote a few days ago we need to think like all the top universities do and act like they do. Study like UCL was #1, work as hard as if UCL was #1, put in the extra shift as if UCL was #1. We can change this and we can bring UCL back to the top.
#BLEEDPURPLE

While most people will view this issue under the lecturer-student relationship, I will just like to draw your attention to relationships between PhD students and undergrads. If Iâ€™m not wrong (PhD students please correct me on this) PhD students are informed during their orientation week that theyâ€™re severely discouraged from forming romantic relationships with students, as it will impair the teaching and the potential bias involved. This is an aspect that isnâ€™t highlighted enough but is becoming an increasingly prevalent issue in universities worldwide. While the age gap at first doesnâ€™t seem too large (5-6 years), itâ€™s the power imbalance that exist within this relationship that is fundamentally problematic.
Whether this PhD student is teaching the undergrad or not, itâ€™s still fundamentally not right, as they are technically a paid member of staff. Itâ€™s basically a teacher-student relationship. It makes it even more exploitative if there is a relationship then, as the PhD student is aware of the consequences of such actions and have been forewarned against such relationships. And I cannot stress enough that this can happen to anyone, regardless of your gender and sexual orientation. I hope with UCL putting out a public statement on its stance on the matter, more open discussions can be made regarding this issue in UCL in the future, to increase awareness of the vulnerability of young people and to increase support for those who unfortunately have been victims of this exploitation.
I believe that most, if not almost all PhD students are not like this, and never intent to take such actions, but to the select few who still believes itâ€™s okay because your undergrad of choice is â€œmatureâ€ or â€œlegalâ€, here are a few choice words for you.
Youâ€™re a creep and an exploitative adult.

text:
#UCLove70752
To the honourable gentleman, who said UCL is ruining it's reputation, because of hosting courses such as Professional Policing.
I am a Security and Crime Science Student at UCL. UCL was the very first university, to start teaching theoretical and practical Master and then Bachelor level courses in these areas, which, by the way, also include policing. Whilst my point of view might therefore be biased, at least I have an idea what I am talking about, without judging a book by its cover.
Since UCL 's Security and Crime Science Department can be considered a major success story, as it is one of a kind in the world, and more importantly, nearly 100% of students are immediately employed, other unis such as Lancester or King's started to develp similar programs, recognising the financial gap and the demand for more educated professionals in the industry.
Yes, there are things that one could just consider bullshit. However, there is an insanely large and ever growing literature, trying to learn the most about real life incidents. The aim of all these programms is to encourage evidence based and problem oriented policing, especially to prevent abuses of power, which we know have seen a lot especially in the US. UCL Explore has more than enough papers, for anyone interested, to look at the literature. Further, whilst most people will get stuck in a couple of disciplines, researchers in these areas utilize an extremely wide range of disciplines, including psychology, criminology, behavioural genetics, neuroscience, systems and engineering studies, stats and modelling, basic chemistry and physics and so on...
So therefore, for example chemists are absolutely right claiming that we will never know chemistry like they do, but the point is, we don't need to. We just need to understand the basics (of e.g. nerv agents), to guide any decisions later on based on actual scientific evidence, instead of hunches or feelings. So basically, our job is to support all of you from nr. 1 education to engineering, or even management. Gathering and synthetizing the evidence across the disciplines, and then guiding informed decision making.
So if you have no idea what this stuff is, educate yourself. Might come handy in these days with the american crisis. And if you were to critique papers on quality or methodology please do so, that's how scientific progress works. Or at least, this is what they told me here...

#UCLove70747
Can someone please (non-berating and non-aggressively, if you canâ€™t do this, youâ€™re embarrassing your ability to express yourself) the issue people have with students ultimately working for their parents companies?
There are a few people like this in my course and I have noticed that there is a lot of jealousy geared towards them. In UCL in general too.
Although I donâ€™t come from this background, one of my best friends does. Her parents were born in poverty and worked their arses off to build a successful company. It was their personal dream to firstly, build a name and legacy for themselves, and secondly, allow their children to continue this legacy. Theyâ€™re humble but very proud of their accomplishments and Iâ€™m genuinely happy for them too, because I see how much work they put in and the sacrifices they make.
So why does it bother people if she chooses to work for them? Sheâ€™s at university studying to equip herself with the skills to make her own contribution. She works hard and wants to make her parents proud too. I understand that itâ€™s definitely easier than having to look for a job, but why is her effort discredited?
Iâ€™m genuinely confused because I feel like nobody else shares my opinion so Iâ€™m trying to find the hole in it. Yes, itâ€™s a privilege, but there are hundreds of privileges, and life was never said to be fair. Nobody is entitled to what someone else has (except for taxpayer money which should be funding social development and not militarising the police, #BLM).
She may be lucky, but do you expect people like her to refuse to accept that job just because every single other person doesnâ€™t have this opportunity? If this is the case then none of us should eat a meal because not everyone has one. #UCLove70741
https://www.google.com.sg/amp/s/amp.theguardian.com/education/2020/feb/20/ucl-to-ban-intimate-relationships-between-staff-and-students-univesities
You arenâ€™t â€œmatureâ€ for your age, theyâ€™re a creep.
Itâ€™s alluring, for someone 5-6 years older than you to pay you special attention, to say youâ€™re mature for your age. It might even be your first serious relationship. After all, itâ€™s exhilarating that this adult will want to even hang out with you. Theyâ€™re so cool and have so many exciting things to show and talk to you about. You might even shared a multitude of common interests together.
Only itâ€™s not. Think about it, why would an adult nearing their mid-20s or even older, be interested in a teenager. When youâ€™re at that age, youâ€™re so vulnerable. Youâ€™re in a new school, possibly new country, barely 18 and still figuring who you are. Think of it from your perspective, will you want to hang out with someone 5-6 years younger than you? The word â€œmatureâ€ unfortunately scares me now. Itâ€™s the words these groomers and adults use to evoke a sense of exclusivity and recognition that I craved at that age.
Thatâ€™s exploitation. Thereâ€™s a power imbalance that will always exist within those relationship.
Whether youâ€™re male or female or go by non-binary terms, it can happen to anyone. Grooming can happen to anyone at any age, and regardless of gender or sexual orientation. And it thrives in silence and the exploitation of trust. Itâ€™s difficult to identify it, your feelings and emotions say otherwise, but take a moment to think through the situation. You may not even be aware. This didactic relationship exposes you so much risks. If you need to keep your relationship discreet, think about why do you even need to keep it discreet in the first place.
Thereâ€™s a reason why UCL has banned it.
Be careful.

#UCLove70740
The following is a true story
Ok so basically not long ago some guys from my hall went to ministry and I decided to take the mature decision and not go as I had a 9am lecture the next day. So I got an early night and slept at about 11pm. At roughly 12-1AM, I get woken up by someone I know who went to ministry. He was extremely drunk and 2 other people were helping him walk back to halls. I saw through the window that he wasnâ€™t looking great so I decided to quickly change and help him to get back into his room. He was making loud noises on the way so I put my hand on his mouth to prevent other residents of the hall being woken up. I helped him and I actually saved him from falling down the stairs and hitting his head on the floor on several separate occasions. If it wasnâ€™t for me, that guy would have been seriously injured and potentially be in hospital or even dead. I knew I did the right thing and he should be thankful for what I did. None of the other guys helped him in any way shape or form.
He still seemed pretty drunk when he got to his room. So we went to bed and I woke up the next day fine. I wanted to make sure he was ok, so I messaged him to ask him if he was alright as I didnâ€™t see him the whole day. I go to my lectures and let time pass. I open my phone again and this fucktard has the audacity to leave me on read not realising that I potentially saved his life. I think he was at least over the drink limit and he should be lucky that I didnâ€™t report him to the police or even his parents. He should at least have the maturity and intellectual capacity to say something like â€œyeah Iâ€™m fine, thanks for askingâ€ or â€œthank you for taking me to my roomâ€. See this is the sort of idiots youâ€™ll come across in university, I donâ€™t even know how tf he got into UCL. I knew he was fully sober so there was no way he was reading his messages while drunk.
I know this happened a while ago but things like this you donâ€™t forget. He was just being a dick and didnâ€™t want to admit it. He should at least have the decency to apologise for his poor behaviour and he didnâ€™t even do that. Even if he messaged me saying sorry or apologises in the comments today, thatâ€™ll be fine and I can put this whole thing behind me.
Just be glad you havenâ€™t come across these sort of people. You can just tell thatâ€™s heâ€™s the sort of person who will drop out of university and end up doing drugs and living on the street. I can just imagine what would happen if his parents found out.
What are your thoughts on this?

Hey students of UCL! You will likely have seen many posts recently detailing ways that you can get involved with the Black Lives Matter movement.
A team of students have developed Write For Change, a website that auto-composes personalised emails to your local MP, in support of the ongoing protests.
Simply go to the website:
https://www.write-for-change.uk/
Enter your name and address (which are NOT stored), and instantly view, edit, and send each email.
Demanding action from our local constituencies is one of the easiest and most effective ways of helping to support the cause, so please spend just one minute of your time to make a difference.

WANT TO BE A POTENTIAL LIFESAVER LOCKDOWN?
UCL Marrow are the student branch of the national charity Anthony Nolan, who saves the lives of people with blood cancer. Their aim is to sign up students to the stem cell register.
Right now, white Europeans have a 69% chance of finding the best possible match, whilst people from black, asian and ethnic minority backgrounds have only 20.5% chance. Diversifying the register can help to address this imbalance and work to ensure that nobody dies waiting for lifesaving stem cells, regardless of their ethnicity.
If you're interested, please sign up - it is so easy and quick, and you could go on to save a life by doing something so simple!
To find more information and sign up, go to www.anthonynolan.org/uclmarrow

text:
#UCLove70731
Given all the protests about colonial figures statues and memorials currently, I'm reminded of the the fact that the memorial stone outside the student centre to the Choshu Five, one of whom is Ito Hirobumi, is still standing. A previous poster said this around a year ago, but nothing seems to have been done about it.
A number of Japanese students, among the first to study in Europe, studied at UCL since most other British universities at the time required students to be Christians. One of them, Ito Hirobumi was Japan's first prime minister. His western education made him a key figure in the Meiji Restoration, which led to Japan becoming an industrial and modern power. However, he was also the first Resident-General in colonial Korea. His tenure ultimately ended after his assassination at the hands of a Korean nationalist, who viewed him as a symbol of the annexation and colonisation of Korea by the Japanese.
Hirobumi clearly has a complex legacy, particularly since it seems he initially opposed the wholesale annexation of Korea. However, as the first colonial ruler of Korea, which endured many decades of colonial occupation during which Koreans were made to feel inferior in their own country, he is definitely a reviled figure in East Asia. I am not sure if the memorial should be removed, given that the Choshu Five were such an important part of Japan's history. However, the fact that UCL so uncritically displays this memorial, without explaining the imperialistic legacy of the students is somewhat inconsistent. On the UCL website, Hirobumi is simply listed as the first prime minister of Japan. This would kind of be like having Rhodes listed as an alumni simply noting he was a minister of the Cape Colony, without mentioning that he was involved in British Imperialism.
https://www.ucl.ac.uk/about/who/history/famous-alumni

Hi! I hope everyon'es staying healthy!
I was wondering if anyone would be willing to do a language exchange in French with me? Or perhaps know any friends or family who would like to practice their English or Spanish?
I'm at a fairly high level in French (B2/C1 on the CEFR), and am a native English speaker and near-native Spanish speaker, so I am willing to do a Language Exchange in either of these two languages.
My plan is over an hour's session, speak in English or Spanish for half an hour, then in French for the 2nd half hour (so both parties can get language practice in).
Post down below if you're interested or know someone who is interested and I'll dm you.

If I multiply my hourly rate of teaching [ Â£9000/(lectures + seminar) ] by the those that I missed the total is at least double the amount they're offering and am dissatisfied. Apologies for bringing the ever-dominant dollar to the fore but this is about articulating the expectation and rights of the students as customer - as is the present case.
P.S. can anybody see a flaw in this grand plan? at first I worried the Â£Â£Â£ would come out of the teachers' salaries but that conclusion would lead to further strikes and be too illogical for even UCL management.

text:
#UCLove70560
Are any other first years terrified of the feeling that uni is already just slipping by?
Our first year lasted a whole of six months and we're incredibly lucky to even have had that experience but at least to me, it felt a bit too good to be true, and now I see why I had that feeling. Just all seems really shit that we have two and a half years of having fun at university and being in this non-judgemental atmosphere where we will get along with more people than anywhere else in life, and then it's on to working life and getting emotionally drained by hostile competitive colleagues until we retire. Really don't know how I would ever manage to be this happy again after uni ends and people grow up and f off to live their own lives
Hopeful comments appreciated under this, sorry for the sad post

The focus question being â€˜What is the role of tiger parenting in the construction of British Chinese studentsâ€™ learner identities?â€™
As many of you may agree, the British Chinese community as a whole are often underrepresented in both society and in academia, therefore I would love to take this opportunity to shed light to British Chinese students and their perspective on how â€˜tigerâ€™ parents, Chinese culture and their upbringing plays a role in shaping their learner identity (this may include your achievements/ expectations; aspirations; wellbeing) and values towards education!

#UCLove70406
With all thatâ€™s going on and the amount of praise the NHS is getting, I wanted to give praise to a group of people who have barely been mentioned in the news or on social media, nor have been given any discounts on anything.
Shop workers in Asda, Tesco, Lidl, Sainsburyâ€™s etc are all working extra hours, putting their lives at risk, and making sure this nation is well stocked up on not only the essentials but luxuries as well.
As someone who has worked in a shop stacking shelves to fund my degree, I know how hard it is to do the same job day in day out, for very little money, and very little recognition - in fact most people look at you at like they are above you. if they decided to go on strike, quit and stay at home, this country would fall apart far quicker than if the NHS disbanded.
Show your respect to these people, even a simple thank you when someone serves you at the shop goes a long way.
This is not a dig at the NHS because I am Of course undeniably grateful for the hard work staff are doing, but at least they have access to PPE and can wear it all the time, have the moral of the population, knowledge they get rewards and discounts on services outside the NHS, and fundamentally a wage considerably higher than shop workers.
Work is work no matter if youâ€™re a doctor or a cleaner at Asda. No one is greater than anyone else and ANYONE serving this country during this crisis deserves praises irrespective of their background.
Thank you

Hi UCL Students, we are Students for Rent Strike.
With the spread of COVID-19 we all have limited access to teaching, our libraries and even our accommodation.We don't think it's fair that we continue to subsidise Universities running only half its operations with rent money for accommodation we have been advised to leave, when we could be helping our families and saving for the hard times ahead.
Join us in our demand that summer term rent for university provided accommodation forgiven or refunded to students, across the UK. If we stand together and refuse to pay our voices will be heard, join a growing list of students at universities across the country and join our demand that we be treated fairly in this time of crisis.
https://www.facebook.com/StudentRentStrike/

text:
#UCLove70313
UCL students, please can you show a bit more respect and kindness towards people with ASD.
I'm so tired of getting funny looks, being ignored or talked about behind my back. I know I come across as a bit abnormal, and sometimes I talk a lot in lessons and I'm not always aware that other people are bored or would like to talk also. It's not personal or rudeness, it's just my brain.
Most days I come home feeling absolutely shit, trying not to cry because I've offended someone again or made them feel uncomfortable. I go over conversations again and again in my head trying to figure out where I missed up and what I said that has made that person withdraw socially from me. There's no cure, fuck me I wish there were, so please just be nicer and make my life a bit easier.

Seriously, does UCL faculty have access to this facebook page? If not, they should. These are the purest emotions we share at times like this. They should have access to how students face mental, economic, and societal struggles due to coronavirus. Even if they can't come up with effective measures immediately, it would be nice to know that they care -- some students are considering to drop out, live in fear of racism, undergo depression, etc. We can't focus academically while deadlines still exist. We are sad of our missing educational opportunities. UCL should know how we feel.
