"hissy fit by postdocs/PGTAs"
Let's talk about that. PGTAs are often PhD students. PhD students in the UK get on average Â£15k for 12 months. They have no choice but to be PGTAs in the department, sometimes even often forced. They work on zero hour contracts. If the labs get cancelled, they aren't paid. They are not trained either. PGTAs have tried for many years to get better contracts, UCL simply won't listen.
We had to take this action, focus on your blame on UCL and demand for a refund on your lost education. Don't blame other students who are in similar/worse positions than you are.

Dear first-year econ students, (and geography students too!)
It's been a bloody awful year for you with all the strikes and now Corona virus as a cherry on top of the worst pie in existence.
I don't know what will happen with your exams (fingers crossed they're cancelled!) but in case they're not I thought I'd share my notes from last year to help you out.
This link will take you to a google drive folder with notes for ECON0002, ECON0007 (World economy) and for any first year Geography students/anyone taking this as an optional GEOG0007 (Human Ecology). It also includes a document with links to quizlet quizzes for ECON0002, ECON0010, ECON0005, ECON0007 and GEOG0007.
LINK: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1P0jRUdEAK4JzIrwQAJrIbT4fMW5c1h1W
These all served me well last year and I hope you will find them helpful.
Love,
A second year Econ student

text:
#UCLove69921
A Request for UCL to change their current stance on assessments
https://www.ipetitions.com/petition/a-request-for-ucl-to-change-their-current-stance
People may have different opinions on this, but I think the stance UCL is taking on exams so far isnâ€™t appropriate for the situation. I know its a new challenge for them, but it seems at the moment that exams will go on in a way as similar to normal as possible. Weâ€™ve been told we won't be disadvantaged, but also not advantaged. Considering weâ€™ve already missed so much teaching this year. Then for the last bit of teaching, and all of revision, we have a pandemic. Asking us to carry on working as normal seems like madness. If the university isn't going to provide better measures for us assessment wise, the situation is most definitely going to disadvantage us. If it may not disadvantage you in particular, please think about all the other people that it might. The current stance UCL has, to me seems to neglect both fairness, and their students' mental and physical health as priorities. Most likely, the situation is going to get much worse and i really think instead of having to prioritise work, we should be given space to look after ourselves and older people in our communities. Iâ€™m putting this out here to see if other people agree that we should have more appropriate and flexible style assessments that give us this additional space. I think it's important to say something before decisions get emailed out.
The issues at hand are described in more detail below
1. A high volume of students are dealing with family strife - unable to return home or being forced to. Travel is dangerous. The displacement caused by sudden uprooting is mentally and physically draining.
2. The pandemic is having a drastic effect on the economy. Families may come under financial hardship and students may be unable to pay their rent or afford their shopping.
3. Many students that have gone home are in different time zones and may not be able to attend online classes or sit exams
4. Not everyone has access to reliable internet, computers or suitable work environments at home.
5. It may turn out that many people are personally affected by loved ones catching the virus, some of these likely to be quite serious cases. It is immoral to expect students to revise in such a scenario
6. Due to strikes, we will have missed many weeks of taught classes, 2 of which will be online. We are missing over half of an entire semester.
7. Across campus, many buildings are likely to be close due to the virus.
8. As material in university can be incredibly challenging, tutorials, seminars and in-person contact hours are VITAL to understanding our material.
9. Further, personal engagement is essential to most people with learning difficulties.
10. With less taught material, we are unable to write engaged and informed essays. In some cases, there is barely any material eligible for examination.
11. Many of our assessments will not be marked before our exams and final essay deadlines. This feedback is critical to good performance in final assessments.
12. Even if the Library remains open, it is a dangerous place to be for immunocompromised people. It is also difficult to be on campus or in the library with the anxiety caused by the virus. Health officials advise all people to engage in social distancing and self-isolation if sick. Going to the library is outside of that recommendation.
13. Debilitating anxiety prevents people from doing their coursework, many people are experiencing this as their personal situations become more strenuous and uncertain.
14. Additionally, many East and Southeast Asian students have been burdened by increased racism and xenophobia in the wake of the virus.
15. Students with existing mental health issues are overburdened by the stress of the virus, lack of support and contact hours.
16. In lieu of full cancellations, some studentsâ€™ degrees are dependent upon examinations - including many STEM students. However, keep in mind that not everyone has a reliable internet connection or access to a home computer, they should have the option to take their mark as is.
17. Mature students and carers have additional responsibilities that impact their ability to complete their work.
Other Universities like UCLA have implemented similar policies.
We do not believe that dissertations should be cancelled, as it is a continuation of the studies we have been doing since last semester and is a meaningful part of our degrees. We do believe that amendments must be made, based on the following facts:
1. Students are cut off from their supervisors - students should receive revised and extended deadlines for dissertation submission.
2. Students whose dissertations rely on access to physical resources - labs, testing equipment, software and books - should receive further leniency, amendments and extensions.
3. Further guidelines should be provided on how to write project reports for students undergoing research projects who have only been able to acquire half as much data as they should have.
As a final plea, we urge you to consider the financial implications the strikes coupled by this virus has on your students. We ask that you consider refunding each student the equivalent amount of at least 4 weeks tuition (Â£3,036.37 for international students), based on the following facts:
1. Students forced to return home and repatriate are incurring even higher costs.
2. We were not taught for 5 weeks straight and endured strikes last semester and in fall of 2019 as well.
3. We did not enroll at this University to take online classes.
4. Our access to resources (academic and supportive) has been denied, either explicitly through the occupation and closed schools or implicitly through anxiety due to the virus. This is also what our tuition covers.
(some these were taken from a similar university of edinburgh petition)

text:
#UCLove69895
In this time of uncertainty and fear, I thought I'd just share a comment I found on Reddit that made me feel better about all the shit that's been going down this year. Hopefully it makes a few other people feel better too!
"In WWII bombs were getting dropped on London. People kept calm and carried on. Black death devastated Europe. Society carried on.
Right now, people are panicked. 'If I was wrong about this, what else am I wrong about?' We know the world is about to change, but we don't know what it's going to look like yet. That's scary. But in a few weeks we'll know. And then things will get less scary. People will adapt. We'll figure out a way to move through this. Humanity has always found a way to adapt and keep going. Scarier and far more destructive things have happened. We carry on. our generation has had a fairly easy time so far, so it's hard to feel this right now. But looking throughout history, the message is clear, people always go on. Society always carries on.
We're very cynical in the modern age. It's easy to think everyone is a dick bag sometimes. But the true picture of humanity is the 99.99% of drivers in traffic everyday. We all work together. We get to where we need to go. We all basically follow the rules. Everyone is invested in this thing called society. And most people are going to be doing the right things. Just watch, the first stage in any crisis is panic. The second stage is going to be people coming together in ways that will move you to your core. People will circle the wagons and take care of each other. That's what people always do."

#UCLove69891
due to the virus, i had to return home -- which for me is a very toxic place full of bad memories. part of the reason why i chose to come to the uk for my education was to leave my home environment in the first place. for the past four days i've been crying and completely unable to do anything at all. i dont have the resources i need here. i left on a very short notice, so all my stuff is still back in halls and it looks like i'll need to pay for term three. my parents start to suffer economically. i have younger siblings that are at home buzzing with energy and thus, LOUD. i have numerous household chores because all the family's constantly home and so everything is chaos - and my parents for some reason think i have no obligations whatsoever for university, so they treat me like their maid. on top of that, a friend passed away (not from the virus). my grandma has gone completely nuts with panic so i constantly have to be there for her emotionally. im considering just dropping out and giving up because regardless of any attempts i make to establish a normal life someplace wherever, they're always sabotaged. i know this is a very selfish way to look at things, but i cant help it.

text:
#UCLove69870
To all UCL Students:
Although the Coronavirus outbreak is getting worse and worse(with the UK suffering from nearly 2000 cases at the time of writing), please do not panic and over worry about it, as worrying about the disease too much won't help anything: in fact, this will only take a toll on your mental wellbeing. To those who're panicking, I understand your feelings: I'm a heavy panicker and I know that trying to remain calm in the face of the disease is easier said than done, but please remember that you can still try your best to protect yourself by remaining vigilant and though maintaining your hygiene and avoiding crowds despite the disease's contagious nature, and an effective community response against it can effectively delay the spread of the disease(look what's happening in Hong Kong for example! The main reason that the disease spread very slowly is that everyone knows what to do!) So, to those who're shivering in fear due to the coronavirus, don't be afraid-you can surely overcome the virus considering that you and other people know what to do. Follow government guidelines and make sure that everyone you know knows what to do, and we can all have a nice cold pint and safety wait for all of this to blow over.
To those who are underreacting to the disease though, however; please start to be alert of the disease. It's much more dangerous than you think-sure, the mortality rate is not high, but the disease is highly contagious and we can't do anything to cure patients other than keeping them alive and hope that their immune system do the job, meaning that once too many people got infected by the coronavirus, it can paralyze the medical system and cause mortality for nCOV and other patients to skyrocket(look what is happening in Italy and Iran for reference). So, please start to be vigilant and be careful before it's too late.
While preparing for the coronavirus, however, don't stockpile on stuff and only get the amount of stuff you need. I know telling you to not panic buy is very clichÃ©d, but a major problem in London is that people panic buy to the extent that a lot of grocery store shelves are empty, and this means that not everyone(especially the ones who are more vulnerable to the disease) can get the things they need due to the selfishness of some paranoid people. So, please, only get the stuff you need so that everyone(including you) can have enough supplies.
Although the whole situation in the UK is looking grim, we can still overcome the disease by remaining safe and delaying it's spread until a cure or vaccine is invented. So please find a balance between being overreacting and underreacting, encourage and educate everyone you'll know about the disease and what we can do, and try your best to remain in your homes following the cancellation of face-to-face classes and exams. Keep calm and carry on, and we can emerge victorious at the end.
P.S: Sorry for my poor English! It's not my first language!

As someone who experienced the death of a close family member at a young age, let me tell you all: your small fears are legitimate. It's things like being able to see your crush or going your favourite takeout that death (and the fear of it) takes away first, and longest, and for many of us, these are what make life worth living. When you look back at this, you will remember those things, and mourn them. Never believe that you don't deserve to feel sad just because other people are in deeper peril.

text:
#UCLove69737
I'm sorry but UCL better give us generous deadline extensions for essays due at the start of term 3. It's not even a case of "oh I'm missing the last two weeks of class I cba to catch up." The entire country (and the world, in fact) is literally coming to a halt and that shit is both draining and mind boggling to even CONSIDER, let alone to experience it. Each day is becoming exponentially more serious, and this is unnerving to say the least. I hope UCL (and I'm sure they will) consider that it's not just the missed classes that warrant mitigation, but the fact that we are in a once in a lifetime situation that is A LOT to take in.
p.s. don't take this post the wrong way: I know the situation is awful and there are people out there losing loved ones, and that there are more important things to worry about all things considered, and I know there are students who are coming off of this worse than I am, however (and I'm sure final year students will vouch for this) these finals are significant enough that they can determine our future for good or for worse, and I wish neither for myself nor for my fellow students to suffer academically because of this pandemic. I feel I'm within my right to express this concern, but don't wish to come across as selfish or narrow minded :)

Email template to try and get released from contracts for third term - if you live in halls please send to accommodation@ucl.ac.uk !!
Dear UCL Accommodation,
I am writing to request a release from my accommodation contract for the third term.
UCL has taken the step of suspending the unseen examination period due to Coronavirus. This means my presence in London for the third term - the sole reason that I engage with your services as a provider of accommodation - has been negated. The decision to suspend the unseen examination period has not followed from any specific advice from Public Health England, and therefore I could not reasonably expect the decision taken by UCL to occur. It seems unreasonable to have to pay for accommodation during an exam period that will no longer occur.
Our colleagues at Queen Mary university have been able to be exit their contracts, and so I am requesting that you follow the precedent set by a fellow University of London member.
Yours sincerely,
post_text:

text:
#UCLove69575
I've been crying all night and I haven't really slept. I feel my ptsd starting to kick back in too. I feel alone and I think self isolating is going to be awful for mental wellbeing. I have a fear that someone is going to break in and harm me and I know it is irrational but I can't stop thinking about it. I think I'm going to go crazy.
I feel so homesick but I think my mum does have underlying health conditions and the last thing I want to do is infect her, I couldn't live with that. I know they want to see me, and I really want to see them, I miss them so much.
I decided a while back to stay in my student accomodation and not to go back home until i know that I wouldn't be infecting anyone. I'm scared that I am asymptomatic and I would hate to be a transmitter of coronavirus to anybody. I know from a previous trauma that I carry guilt really quickly and it becomes a long term pain for me. So it's a lose-lose situation whether or not I go back. My worry is that some of my flatmates are staying for now, but deep down I think they all will go. I really fear being alone. Since a traumatic incident two years ago that left me with PTSD, anxiety and insomnia, I've had to really work on my mental wellbeing and I have a feeling that all my progress is going to unravel and Im scared of not having the strength to get better. I also have done any proper uni work lately but it's something that I've come to accept. I'm really bad at reaching out for help, I'm just hoping that somebody has some advice. Thanks so much.
post_text:
#UCLove69575
I've been crying all night and I haven't really slept. I feel my ptsd starting to kick back in too. I feel alone and I think self isolating is going to be awful for mental wellbeing. I have a fear that someone is going to break in and harm me and I know it is irrational but I can't stop thinking about it. I think I'm going to go crazy.
I feel so homesick but I think my mum does have underlying health conditions and the last thing I want to do is infect her, I couldn't live with that. I know they want to see me, and I really want to see them, I miss them so much.
I decided a while back to stay in my student accomodation and not to go back home until i know that I wouldn't be infecting anyone. I'm scared that I am asymptomatic and I would hate to be a transmitter of coronavirus to anybody. I know from a previous trauma that I carry guilt really quickly and it becomes a long term pain for me. So it's a lose-lose situation whether or not I go back. My worry is that some of my flatmates are staying for now, but deep down I think they all will go. I really fear being alone. Since a traumatic incident two years ago that left me with PTSD, anxiety and insomnia, I've had to really work on my mental wellbeing and I have a feeling that all my progress is going to unravel and Im scared of not having the strength to get better. I also have done any proper uni work lately but it's something that I've come to accept. I'm really bad at reaching out for help, I'm just hoping that somebody has some advice. Thanks so much.

Iâ€™m a final year international student overwhelmed with emotions as I leave London, not knowing when Iâ€™ll be back or see any of my friends again, knowing that university is basically over, but I just want to address everyone freaking out about fees and online exams:
1. UCL in no way is liable to give you a refund. This situation isnâ€™t something they could somehow have avoided. I
Would you rather they go ahead with classes?
2. Exams are likely to be more leniently marked and externally examined due to the circumstances they were taken in. Iâ€™m reasonably sure that our lecturers are more worried than we are, so we must have faith that they will do whatâ€™s best for us.
3. Itâ€™s incredibly selfish to say exams should be cancelled instead of moved online and graduation delayed â€” some of us have jobs and masters degrees to go to and I speak for my friends as well as myself when I say that weâ€™re so so so thankful that UCL is caring about our health and safety while also ensuring weâ€™re able to graduate as planned. Not being able to do that would be catastrophic.

A third year writing here...this whole thing with the cancelled exams and potential coursework substitutions or open book exams is just not working for me, and Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s not working for a lot of people. I chose most of my modules to be exam based purely because my half-arsed time management always screws up my coursework quality, while for exams my short term memory and revision techniques are great. Extra coursework will severely diminish quality of the dissertations we all have to write. And needless to say all strikes this academic year has severely damaged the quality of our studies and the fact that ucl is not addressing it is just horrid. They should at least give us options, in some cases maybe even redoing a year, or having the opportunity to sit exams later in proper conditions. Not to mention the possible absence of any graduation.

Anyone else really nervous about online exams?? I find it so much harder to concentrate at home compared to in an actual exam hall, and I hate doing my exams from a screen rather than paper. Also, if it ends up being open book (because how are they going to monitor it), I'm worried they'll make it unbelievably time-pressured to solve this, which makes everything so much more stressful. Every online assessment I've done this year has gone shit for this reason.
Anyone else think they should genuinely consider just scrapping exams this year because it won't properly assess how well we know content and is totally unfair because it's so different to past years. Or at least reduce the weighting of this year for the overall degree. If anyone else has ideas to get around the issues with online testing please comment and we might be able to posit solutions to department heads.

You have no idea the number of hours, days, weeks, months that go into organise and preparing for events like these. The blood sweat and tears performers and committee put in to make these shows and events happen. Not to mention these are the equivalent to a part-time job for which they get ZERO payment, other than the satisfaction of knowing that they've created something they're proud of.
If you have an issue with something somebody else has put in an enormous amount of effort to put together, either join committee, take part, or keep it to yourself.
post_text:

To all the people who feel the need to discredit shows and events societies put on, no matter how big or small.
Please shut the fuck up.
You have no idea the number of hours, days, weeks, months that go into organise and preparing for events like these. The blood sweat and tears performers and committee put in to make these shows and events happen. Not to mention these are the equivalent to a part-time job for which they get ZERO payment, other than the satisfaction of knowing that they've created something they're proud of.
If you have an issue with something somebody else has put in an enormous amount of effort to put together, either join committee, take part, or keep it to yourself.

text:
#UCLove69126
*Beware of scams*
Someone approached me near cruciform and claims his bags got stole and need some money to take the tube and all in his possession are his keys and an oyster card.
He or she might claim she works nearby (eg in euston).
Here are some tips:
1. Never give them cash, eg tell them you dont carry any
2. Ask them where do they work and live and call the place to see they actually work there
3. Ask them some simple questions such as which direction places are and what not
4. Question why they are here at your current location
Its okay wanting to be nice and help someone else out, but who wants to be scammed innit?
post_text:
#UCLove69126

#UCLove68916
Hey everyone! It's me, duck girl, back to announce that I have my own ducks now!! Meet Sir Francis Drake and Mr Darcy, two absolutely stunning Indian Runner ducks that I would actually die for!!! Their favourite activities include rootling around in a bucket full of mud and grass, running around their temporary pen (we haven't finished the proper one yet) and tripping up all the time, preening, and watching the pheasants run past their pen.
Once the main pen is finished we will be able to get five more drakes from a local rescue - we're having a little bachelor flock! - three more runners, a pekin and a chunky Aylesbury with arthritis called Mr Beep Beep! I'm living my best life.
post_text:
#UCLove68916
Hey everyone! It's me, duck girl, back to announce that I have my own ducks now!! Meet Sir Francis Drake and Mr Darcy, two absolutely stunning Indian Runner ducks that I would actually die for!!! Their favourite activities include rootling around in a bucket full of mud and grass, running around their temporary pen (we haven't finished the proper one yet) and tripping up all the time, preening, and watching the pheasants run past their pen.
Once the main pen is finished we will be able to get five more drakes from a local rescue - we're having a little bachelor flock! - three more runners, a pekin and a chunky Aylesbury with arthritis called Mr Beep Beep! I'm living my best life.

text:
#UCLove68856
Trigger Warning: Depression
.
.
.
.
.
.
I hate to say this out loud but UCL sucks big time. My experience in this university has been nothing short of an ordeal, and with each passing day, it has only become worse. I have tried my best to engage with people, to make friends, to take part in as many societies I can (realistically), but the past one year has been the one of the most depressing time of my life. All my efforts have failed, and I no longer enjoy my classes or my course, I have no friends and I have lost the will to do pretty much everything. Not a day goes by when I am contemplating whether to kill myself or not, and while I try my best to put up a brave face everyday, I'm being eaten alive on the inside. I just want it to stop

text:
#UCLove68706
Trigger Warning: depression
.
.
.
.
I've had depression since first year, I'm now in third year and i've been going to therapy for a year now. Although therapy was incredibly helpful the past month has been very hard and it affected my studies. I know that if I continue like this I might not graduate or risk doing very badly, wasting the past 3 years of hard work. I'm thinking of taking antidepressants but I've read that it takes months to get used to them and for them to actually be helpful. Given that I have only 2 and a half months left until my degree is over I'm worried that the side effects will just disorient me even more than depression itself. I know that different medication has different effects and the best thing to do is consult my gp but I'd like to gain some insight on how the first period of taking the antidepressants really is before starting to pursue this option so if anyone feels comfortable sharing their experience it would be really helpful.

text:
#UCLove68685
Can people please stop 'glorifying' procrastination?
It doesn't make you funky or edgy. It also (contrary to popular belief) doesn't make it more impressive if you do well in your subject/a test. Especially when you say you're not working hard at all, if you are or are not, and then brag about your results.
Some people with cognitive disorders genuinely find it very hard to get down to work, and might have to put in 10x more hours than you to get the same grade. I know in an academic environment people enjoy competing and 'getting one over' on each other - and that's totally fine! But please be aware of others that it might not come as natural to

Aight fellas,
What's the BBC doing? Is this a sick joke?
Check it out:
Pls see attached img.
GTA IV which can be seen in the image, was not released on the PlayStation 2.
The controller seen in the picture is a six axis controller, not dualshock 2. This is clear from the fact that a wire cannot be seen coming out of the controller, and more obviously from the circular PlayStation home button. The dual shock 2 did not have these features.
Therefore they were using a PlayStation 3 in the image.
The PlayStation 2 recently turned 20. Show some respect you twats.

text:
#UCLove68624
I am so sorry that this is an event promotion post/fundraising ask and not a confession, but hope that you'll read on anyway <3
Are you Filipino and want to help support an awesome cultural festival with games, activities, and food all about the Philippines? Are you not Filipino but want to know more about the culture and support something that UCL students (and other uni students from around the UK) have worked really hard on? Then this is the post for you.
FiliFest is a Filipino cultural festival organised by students from universities around the UK and is happening for the second time this summer at UCL!
We would love to see members of the UCL community there (exact date TBA but tentatively 6th of June)! I am actually making this post to ask for your guys' help to fundraise the event. It is 100% student organised and student run so we could use all the help we could get. Even if it's just Â£1 or Â£2, any help would be very much appreciated!
The link to the FiliFest trailer, social media details, and the fundraiser can be found below. If you got this far, thank you for reading!
FiliFest 2020 Trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9VerUjzZet0
Fundraiser: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/fili-fest
FiliFest Socials: Instagram @filifest Facebook FiliFest

I have been struggling with my identity as an artist and an environmentalist/anti-consumerist. I'm going to be blunt - I feel that most of the work that we make at the Slade 1) isn't of high quality, 2) has no practical value to society and 3) will end up as trash. Honestly, the amount of waste that the Slade produces is insane. People just create stuff for the sake of experimentation without a care for the environment. I don't understand how we, a liberal majority, can claim to be aware of environmental issues, yet are completely ok with what we do.

text:
#UCLove60812
In a state of constant existential crisis. I like this uni. I like my course. And yet, it feels like something's missing. And I don't really know what it is. Maybe it's just that I don't have a girlfriend and I would really like one, but then that's not the only thing on my mind either. The future just generally seems bleak, and I'm anxious about it. This crisis was out to get me since I did my GCSEs, but I've just been putting it off. I told myself to focus on A levels and then life would be good once I got to uni. And so I struggled through 2 gruelling years of 4 A levels, 2 of which were in subjects I wasn't even interested in by the time I got to year 13. I got my As and A*s, and I got into UCL. But now that I'm here, although it is a great uni, it's kind of just the same. You're set work and you're expected to do it. Ok so there's more flexibility etc but either way you're given work to do, you do the work, and you go home. And when you get home, you're just so alone until you go into uni the next day. And then when you graduate and get a job, it's more or less the same thing, except that you get paid for it too. Is this all there is to it? Is this what I'm meant to do for the next 50 years and then die? Something needs to change. I'm certainly not going to kill myself, but I'm not entirely sure what I want to do with my life either. But I want to do something before I develop unhealthy coping mechanisms. Ok so I guess staying up really late and spamming uclove isn't exactly healthy, but it's far less unhealthy than having a drink/drug/smoking problem. Idk what the problem is, but I guess it's just that I thought adult life would be ... different.

#UCLove60172
Imagine if boris johnson proposed a new law and the whole of Greater London, West Midlands, West Yorkshire and Hampshire protested peacefully and said â€œhey we donâ€™t want itâ€. But not only did the police shoot you with a bunch of tear gas and rubber bullets to make you go away, boris simply said â€œokay Iâ€™ll put it on hold but it doesnâ€™t mean I wonâ€™t bring it up againâ€.
Thatâ€™s essentially what happened and is still happening in Hong Kong.
First things first I would like to make it clear that independence is NOT demanded. So mainlanders who donâ€™t have a clear understanding about the demands please sit down.
The protests have been going on for almost 6 months and I think at this point we canâ€™t just look at the incidents separately. Itâ€™s obviously wrong to set roadblocks and throw Molotov cocktails but we must remember that the protests were peaceful when it first started in June. One million HKers made it clear that they were against the extradition law yet their voices werenâ€™t even acknowledged. HK is a small city with approximately 7 million citizens. One million people in HK demonstrating is almost like the whole London protesting. But the government ignored these voices.
HKers have displayed their capability to march and demonstrate peacefully but the government and police responded with violence. Tear gas and rubber bullets were fired at protesters who were not posing a threat, who were retreating, who were not showing any sign of aggression.
Now Iâ€™m not saying protesters are not violent at all. Bricks and Molotov cocktails were thrown, the legislative council was stormed and trashed, police have been injured etc. I personally donâ€™t always agree with protestersâ€™ actions but I can understand why they did it. Up to two million people spoke out against the extradition bill peacefully and the government still didnâ€™t take public opinions seriously. What would you do if it happened to you?
Some people think HKers are only protesting because we are sinophobic so we are against anything associated with China. I canâ€™t speak for everyone but personally I do not want to be associated with the Chinese communist party. I donâ€™t dislike China as a country. I love our history and culture. But I do not support the Chinese communist party. The party that rules and controls its people with oppression and lies, bans all religion and locks millions of Muslims in concentration camps, â€œre-educateâ€ Muslims by forcing them to eat pork, learn mandarin, rape them, inject them with unknown drugs and even murder them. Thanks but no thanks. I would like to keep my freedom of speech and rights to criticise the government.
I always see comments such as â€œthose rioters have been so violent and destructive they should be arrested and punishedâ€. But thousands of people have been arrested, even people who were just passing by. The youngest arrested is 11 and the oldest is in their 80s. On the other hand, the police have been abusing their power and weapons, forcing their way into private premises without a warrant, attacking journalists and deliberately running protesters over with vehicles. Now I could bang on about the countless incidents of police brutality but if youâ€™re interested, you can search it up on Twitter and instagram. Thousands of protesters have been arrested and not even one police officer has been punished for their actions.
This blatant corruption is why the protests are escalating. The government tried to silence opposing opinions the CCP way - oppression and violence.
Peoplesâ€™ lives are disrupted and itâ€™s easy to blame the protesters, saying they are ruining the society and economy. But who wouldnâ€™t rather hang out with friends, stay in bed and enjoy their youth than to risk their lives and be bombarded with cyanide and dioxin? This isnâ€™t fun but itâ€™s necessary. If we donâ€™t fight now, itâ€™s going to be impossible in the future.
If youâ€™re still reading, thank you, and please stand with Hong Kong.

text:
#UCLove54783
#UCLove54575
A while back there was this post that was a bit unsympathetic towards leave voters who now seem to be shocked that brexit is not some kind of fairytale. I just want to say I really don't understand some of the comments. For example, the one starting with "Maybe if you stepped off your high horse to examine the harsh economic conditions of those who voted for Brexit". I, as an EU citizen, really don't have to be understanding of those people. Moreover, don't you think it's a bit offensive that you seem to be suggesting that because of someone's socio-economic background they wouldn't be able to make proper decisions. Adults are adults and they should be held accountable for their decisions. If they were children, they wouldn't be allowed to vote. In this world, we are judged by our decisions. It's perfectly fine to judge someone who voted for Brexit. It was their decision. Yes, politicians were misleading. But, ultimately, they were adults who made their own decisions and are now whining gloriously about it.
post_text:
#UCLove54783
#UCLove54575

text:
#UCLove52803
Why are gender identity and sexuality grouped under the same term 'LGBTQ+'. I say this as a gay man who is a supporter of the trans community. While both communities still have a long way to go in terms of equality, the LGB definitely has a lot more recognition and has received a lot more attention in recent years, whilst I feel it is much harder to be a member of the trans community in today's society. I worry that we hail LGBT progress when we are actually only really seeing progress for the LGB community and the trans community is being left behind. But because they all come under the same banner we forget about trans issues.
Also sexuality and gender identity are two completely separate issues. Yes, gay people can support the trans community (and vice versa) but we will never truly understand what it means to question your gender identity. The label LGBTQ+ feels to me like "Oh these people aren't 'normal' let's shove them all under the same label".
post_text:

Hi, I've been putting of posting this but I can't any longer. My mental health hasn't been great since starting uni (particularly on the anxiety front) and alongside this I have unhealthy coping mechanisms which hinder my ability to get much work done during term time. I then beat myself up mentally because of it all. I feel like over the past year in particular (2nd year), I'm just lost within myself and that I've lost track of what I truly want in life. To top it all off, there are 2 exams in particular (out of the remaining ones I have) which I'm so anxious about (I've had a few breakdowns, periods of negative thoughts, etc.) that I continue to procrastinate studying for them, and whenever I do sit down to try and do work for those modules, I just mentally can't bring myself to do it because of how fearful I feel. I just don't know what to do I want to defer but I just don't know whether it's possible
post_text:

Trigger Warning: ableism
.
.
.
.
.
I hate being disabled. It's a constant battle to be recognised by anyone, by doctors, by uni staff, even by your friends. The people I thought I was genuinely close to abandoned me the moment I became the slightest bit inconvenient to them. Every interaction I have with doctors is full of gaslighting and patronisation. So many people think you are worthless if you don't work, they don't care to see how much you struggle with the things you can do.
What is the point of living when the world absolutely despises you for what you are?

The staff are friendly and relaxed (with 24hr reception).
The price is Â£329 a week, a discount may be negotiable.

#UCLove47645
Coming from an extremely conservative society, just a friendly word of caution for people with the view, "The female only gym-hours are just few hours, Get Over Yourself or Make a Sacrifice etc".
In my 30yrs there, I have seen how these small steps of segregation cascade into steps resulting in a completely divided society where even having a conversation or a hello with your colleague from opposite gender becomes a suspicious act (while typing this, saw #UCLove47480 suggesting men-only gym hours!). It always starts with 'its not a big deal', so just be aware.
Do not be dismissive of the underlying principle till it becomes an issue which you can not undo even if you wish to.

#UCLove36924
#UCLove36856
Alright kiddos, buckle up [technically y'all are older than me, but I'm dropping the edumacation rn, so listen up!]
All this about priviledge and racism and whatever else y'all have been hollering... It's getting out of hand.
We're all UCL students, and we are all going to be amongst the best at whatever we do. I don't need to know about where y'all came from or whatever and likewise my personal life needn't make any difference to you guys.
Naturally, certain social factors and genetic components do make life "easier" or "harder" for some people compared to others, but that's inevitable. I could have been born Bill Gate's son, but I wasn't. I can't control it, and whatever I do won't change my heritage and any privilege I may or may not have received.
Quite frankly, there's no point wasting your energy and thought into things that people can't influence. It's worth more than that. Be proud of what you've achieved on your own accord, and leave other people's lives to them. I don't give a bollocks whether you came from Eton, Ilford or Sri Lanka, I just look at the person in front of me. If they're a piece of work to me, then regardless of who they are, I just won't fuck with them, and they'll explicitly be told why. But equally, if they show me love, I'll be there for them and then some.
About your questions,OP...
You've got the clear insight that being judgemental or making assumptions about people are to be avoided, from which your questions kind of answer themselves really. Just because you don't know things about people doesn't mean you have to automatically just jump to conclusions to fill in those gaps in knowledge - part of getting to know someone is to become comfortable with them and how they communicate with you.
For some people, you might find that they reveal a lot of small things about themselves indirectly, or maybe they just might talk a lot and just tell you things upfront. Other times you might be able to ask them for things you're unsure about in their life.
Just be respectful about it, and if you're unsure there is no real harm in respectfully asking them for some clarification about something you want to know about them. Most people will be happy to tell you these things, provided you don't pry into their personal lives and don't have some weird hidden motive behind knowing.
But also consider this, if you've truly done your best to be considerate towards this other person, and they still have a problem with it, then clearly such a friendship or whatever wouldn't have really worked, because at some level you two just don't see things eye to eye, and at some point the diference in perspectives and behaviours would have flared up. Better to see it early and leave things be than to make some phoned-in attempt to not have your "friendship" pop off.
All in all? Value the human being, not what made them. You can't go wrong with that.
People are nice enough if you give them a chance and treat them with dignity, and if not, walk away.
Sincerely,
Stan
PS [the person and the acronym], you know who I am, but I was never hiding it. I've made this alias clearly associated with me, just like my persona or where I'm at.

Sometimes it can be like that. I recently met a girl from home who likes me and I really like her too, she's really kind and sweet and I think she's good for me - we've been texting for a while now. But at the moment my life just revolves around sleeping, eating and studying at the moment, I don't step out of the house. She asked me if I wanted to meet up for a drink but studying is my priority and I can't see myself getting out of this routine. I feel too busy to date this person or anyone as a matter of fact. But that doesn't mean I'm not interested in her or getting to know this person or eventually having her as my girlfriend. What should I do? I don't feel like I'm ready to date this person yet but just want to talk and see what happens, but I'm worried that she might loose interest and I'll lose her! I don't know what to do because I've been in the opposite situation in the past too and it'd suck to be her! HELP!

â€œYouâ€™re a wizard, Harry,â€ Hagrid said. â€œAnd youâ€™re coming to Hogwarts.â€
â€œWhatâ€™s Hogwarts?â€ Harry asked.
â€œItâ€™s wizard school.â€
â€œItâ€™s not a public school, is it?â€
â€œNo, itâ€™s privately run.â€
â€œGood. Then I accept. Children are not the property of the state; everyone who wishes to do so has the right to offer educational goods or services at a fair market rate. Let us leave at once.â€
â€œMalfoy bought the whole team brand-new Nimbus Cleansweeps!â€ Ron said, like a poor person. â€œThatâ€™s not fair!â€
â€œEverything that is possible is fair,â€ Harry reminded him gently. â€œIf he is able to purchase better equipment, that is his right as an individual. How is Dracoâ€™s superior purchasing ability qualitatively different from my superior Snitch-catching ability?â€
â€œI guess it isnâ€™t,â€ Ron said crossly.
Harry laughed, cool and remote, like if a mountain were to laugh. â€œSomeday youâ€™ll understand, Ron.â€
Professor Snape stood at the front of the room. â€œThere will be no foolish wand-waving or silly incantations in this class. As such, I donâ€™t expect many of you to appreciate the subtle science and exact art that is potion-making. However, for those select few who possess, the predispositionâ€¦I can teach you how to bewitch the mind and ensnare the senses. I can tell you how to bottle fame, brew glory, and even put a stopper in death.â€
Harryâ€™s hand shot up.
â€œWhat is it, Potter?â€ Snape asked, irritated.
â€œWhatâ€™s the value of these potions on the open market?â€
â€œWhat?â€
â€œWhy are you teaching children how to make these valuable products for ourselves at a schoolteacherâ€™s salary instead of creating products to meet modern demand?â€
â€œYou impertinent boyâ€“â€œ
â€œConversely, whatâ€™s to stop me from selling these potions myself after you teach us how to master them?â€
â€œIâ€“â€œ
â€œThis is really more of a question for the Economics of Potion-Making, I guess. What time are econ lessons here?â€
â€œWe have no economics lessons in this school, you ridiculous boy.â€
Harry Potter stood up bravely. â€œWe do now. Come with me if you want to learn about market forces!â€
The students poured into the hallway after him. They had a leader at last.
Harry and Ron stood before the Mirror of Erised. â€œMy God,â€ Ron said. â€œHarry, itâ€™s your dead parents.â€
Harryâ€™s eyes flicked momentarily over to the mirror. â€œSo it is. This information is neither useful nor productive. Let us leave at once, to assist Hagrid in his noble enterprise of raising as many dragon eggs as he sees fit, in spite of our countryâ€™s unjust dragon-trading restrictions.â€

Harry sighed. â€œThe fundamental standard for all relationships is the trader principle, Ron.â€

Can people wait until the students from the previous lecture have left the room? Not only does it make it harder to get in and to get out, but it also goes against the British culture of queuing. the point is everything besides all those other things. there is a lot in the world. there's the stuff you forget about when you're at university busy with things that other people convince you are important, and when you get the time to reconnect with that stuff you remember how much joy you can experience. it is not normal, no, but it has become a habit for your brain to think of dying. you can't be ok 100% of the time and stuff has just become too much, give yourself a break?? youtube is fine if it distracts you. talk to someone in school about your struggles and see if you can have extra time for work etc. people are willing to help and can quickly fix the work part for you. i know you don't want sympathy but i do truly hope you're feeling better soon :< feeling this way really is so horrible.

Tried to quit smoking for ages always relapsed, I tried everything like vaping, patches,gum, cold turkey and theh worked but after a month or two back at it. I always thought using nicotine to quite was stupid as your using the same drug to get off a drug.
But nicotine is an essential thing in my life, the stimulant. I am addicted to it for sure but now i've given vaping a more sincere shot and its going well. I think I'm on the path to quit smoking and hopefully nicotine.
The way i see it now is i'd rather be addicted to something with less harmful effect, cold turkey is defo the most effective way but when stress comes up its too easy to revert.
If you wanna quit i would say give vaping a go it is the lesser of two evils.
With decisions like this you gotta know why you wanna do it. For me its to live longer i got too much I want to do with my life and its already short as it is. I have family and people that I care about and people who don't even exist yet that I will care about and I want to spend as much time as I can with them.
If your friend is trying to quit don't give them ciggerettes just say no cos they do want it and tobacco has got that taste and flavour that a vape just can't deliver so yeah there is still cravings.

#UCLove35819
Before I start, this does not reflect my views on homeless people in general. Only a select few.
I've been at UCL for about two years now. In my first week, I was with a friend and was approached by a homeless woman who told me her story and basically asked for money. I said I had no change and only had money in my card but my friend gave her a couple of pounds. She then turned to us and asked us for more and said to me "there's an atm nearby, we can go there and you can withdraw the money". At which point I walked away and didn't think much of it.
Up until today where I saw the same woman doing the exact same thing to other people in the area. What I don't get is how this person has made zero progress in their life over these two years. I decided to stand nearby having my lunch and eavesdropped and her story was the same word to word. What little shred of sympathy I had got lost instantly since she appears to be a professional rather than someone in genuine need of help.
I'll probably be judged for writing this but beginning to lose sympathy for the homeless people around UCL since I've been seeing the same people for the past two years. How has nothing been done to help their situation? Is it a case of people unwilling to change or our government being shit?

text:
#UCLove25918
> Since there's been some posts about body positivity, as well as some news articles, I thought I would say this:
I know it's a sensitive issue for people, and of course no one should have to feel awful about their image. But 'bodypositivity' can also lead to the trap of embracing an unhealthy life. Being very overweight has clear risks and dangers associated with it, not to mention costs to others in the form of socialized healthcare. It's fine to be positive about yourself, but it would be foolish to use that as a reason to do nothing about your weight. Pretending that there's no problem, or implying that being overweight is just "another shape" is wrong, because that involves lying to yourself and to others. Being honest with yourself is the first step towards living a healthier life.
Sources: I was reasonably overweight for a number of years.

text:
#UCLove25242
#UCLove25210 (comments section)
There's a problem with this transphobia debate. Let's set the scene here. I'm a straight male. Straight means I am attracted to females, and I don't want to touch someone's penis. I like vaginas. Cool.
I meet a wonderful lady and she says she's trans. I'm progressive and liberal and therefore don't want to get put off by this despite my natural, socially normalised biases, so I go on a date with this lady. Sex could be on the cards. Do I:
a) ask if she has a dick or not? Wait no of course I can't. That's transphobic. You wouldn't ask a straight girl about her genitals!
b) wait for sex then find out, then leave if I'm uncomfortable because to expect me to have sexual contact with a penis against my wishes is very problematic. That's transphobic too though right?
c) expect her to tell me what's in her pants? No ofc not, that's transphobic because you wouldn't expect a cis girl to say "hi my name is X and I have a vagina"
d) ask about sexual things in conversation and see if the topic comes up naturally. But that's weird, and might make the girl uncomfortable.
It's such a thorny issue and it's almost impossible not to get yourself in trouble with this and not offend. Sexuality is both a physical and a mental thing but the physical side is very important in my opinion. You can't just dismiss someone not wanting to have sexual contact with a penis as transphobic. And saying that someone might want to do other things instead of penis play is fine but you can't ask a girl you're seeing to plan out sex so that you don't have to have contact with dicks. That is also surely dehumanising to the trans girl.
Assuming that someone doesn't want to be with a trans person just because of the trans title (without thinking any further or wondering what someone might want from a relationship) is little short of virtue signalling.

text:
#UCLove24768
<TRIGGER WARNING: controversial opinion, may make some uncomfortable>
.
.
.
.
I've been reading a lot of emotional abuse posts on this page lately. What's with the "abusers" being made to look like evil genius sociopaths. I'm not doubting that there may be a couple but these are young adults we're talking about. I refuse to believe that the "abusers" were completely at fault for the relationship. Maybe the relationship was abusive but that doesn't mean it's fair to call one of the partners an "abuser". I could take some statements from every relationship I've ever had (platonic or romantic) and post it on here. It's going to look super bad but hate none of my previous relationships. Even my healthy relationship with my parents may have some fucked up statements. I'm sure most of y'all will concur. Context is fucking key. What led up to the statement being said and what occurred following the statement matters a lot more than the statement itself. How can we then judge the "abuser" based on these statements only and sympathise with the abused?
I don't even blame the abused. They probably were dependent on the "abuser" and the relationship may have gone downhill due to this reason. This might have led to realizations that the relationship wasn't that healthy but that doesn't mean their partner was an evil trickster. Add to that our society's obsession with labelling things. The amount of times I've heard 'that relationship is abusive you need to get out ' despite the people knowing jack shit about the relationship itself. Yes the relationship might be abusive but does the '"abuser" even know that. Talk to him/her. Tell them you don't like the words they use and that you expect to be treated better. If they still don't get it and the treatment doesn't change then get he fuck out of there. Even then it may not be because of the intention of the person but because of who the person truly is. Yes this is easier said then done. The abused is in love and is just trying to please the "abuser" so succumbs to the "abuser's" demands. Why is that the "abusers" fault? The abuser probably doesn't even know that the abused doesn't really want to do certain things since there is no communication. The "abuser probably had past relationships where the boundaries were different and the actions weren't shunned. The "abuser" may think everything's going great and the person is meeting all their demands so life is perfect. The "abuser" does probably love the person too and isn't playing some evil game to manipulate the partners feelings. But I guess this form of withdrawal is easier to deal with when you're convinced the person was evil and was out to get you. Makes moving on easier. Its not healthier; just easier. That the person was the villain in your movie and the protagonist is just around the corner. That the person was to blame for how you've been doing in your life or will continue to do in your life. That you've now been scarred forever. Just know that a relationship can end even if both of you were lovely people; you don't have to look back in anger. It's sad that life isn't this black and white. You have to decide if the person is truly worth it and worth fighting for. But the sooner you start recognizing your flaws in the relationship and start working on them instead of thinking you were just naive in love and were exploited the better.
'Abusive' is a strong word to use. We must not instantly shower support on the apparent victim and start vilifying the apparent abuser as readers especially as we don't know the context or the story. We must not discount the extremely deleterious impact that can have on the "abuser" who may not even have been abusive but who is he/she to argue with the majority. Can you imagine the amount of self doubt that creates ?
I've put a TW because the likelihood of those who agree with the post of publically supporting is close to 0. It'd make so much more sense if we could like/comment on this page anonymously too. Like a UCLove reddit. People would be much more supportive and much more honest as there's no fear of being judged by friends. Deeply personal stories can be shared as a a form of therapy too.
I'm not taking any sides and I dont have the right to but i fell we as readers and public commentors of the page have a responsibility and should be as balanced and non judgmental as possible.

I've put a TW because the likelihood of those who agree with the post of publically supporting is close to 0. It'd make so much more sense if we could like/comment on this page anonymously too. Like a UCLove reddit. People would be much more supportive and much more honest as there's no fear of being judged by friends. Deeply personal stories can be shared as a a form of therapy too.
I'm not taking any sides and I dont have the right to but i fell we as readers and public commentors of the page have a responsibility and should be as balanced and non judgmental as possible.

text:
#UCLove24658
So trigger warning (eating disorder, self-harm, recovery)...
.
.
.
.
.
.
Iâ€™ve had mental health issues from like the age of 10. This manifested itself in having disordered eating patterns, and self harming.
Anyway, Iâ€™ve been so much better since university, since leaving both a toxic home and school environment.
And I thought I was doing better, I wasnâ€™t hurting myself, wasnâ€™t holding myself over a tall building trying to find the courage to jump, wasnâ€™t trying to build helium bags to die as painlessly as possible.
I thought I was â€˜overâ€™ it. But on reflection, Iâ€™m not over it yet, and I donâ€™t know whether I ever will be.
It scares the hell out of me because my mental health has gotten in the way of so many dreams and have influenced some of my biggest life decisions.
I just donâ€™t know what to do. I got complacent in my recovery- I havenâ€™t split my skin open in a year. A full year without breaking skin. Thatâ€™s the first time in 5 years. I was proud of that fact till I realised I just replaced one unhealthy coping mechanism with another.
I donâ€™t want my mental health to rule my life anymore but Iâ€™m terrified to get help. I did the whole â€˜getting helpâ€™. My GP put me on a waiting list I never got to the top of, and prescribed anti-depressants which worked for a bit but the side effects were just too much.
Anyway I donâ€™t know what the point of this was. Hopefully I get a grip of myself so I donâ€™t screw things up again

To the person who wrote #UCLove20205 about male pattern baldness --
There's hope! Look into finasteride and minoxidil, you can get a perscription for both pretty easily from your GP. Finasteride works on 90+% of people, and it works really well. Although the side effects are scary, they're extremely rare and relatively overblown. Do your own research, talk to your GP, and see if its right for you. Good luck bro
(P.s. you can get generic finasteride online for really cheap, compared to the brand names sold in pharmacies).

#UCLove20137
Righ let's end it with the xxxtentacion posts. I feel uncomfortable seeing people posting continuously everyday about someones death whether it is to mourn them or being joyful of their death and laughing at those who do mourn them. I understand that the man might have been a monster if the things about his aggressive,abusive,homophobic past or present are true. Not that I haven't done it or felt that way before but it isn't right. Everyone is entitle to feel a certain way but you really don't have to do it consistently on Facebook (that goes also to the people who are mourning). At the end of the day nobody truly knew who he was. No one knew him personally. Whether he rests in peace of deserved it isn't up to any of us. People are difficult and people's life are too. Let's all just be kind to one another and respectful and stop posting shit about the dead. Let it go. If you have to argue over something or post about something let it not be over someone's death.

text:
#UCLove20050
I really just want more people to read this comment from KLJ :)
Life cannot give meaning to you, you have to give meaning to your own life.
You are important because you are a human being: your feelings, your emotions, your experiences and your senses are all valid and enrich the social fabric that is our shared existence and make us all so unique and brilliant - but also terrifying - as a species. You are special because, by complete chance, you've been born into this world with the rest of us - equally created by chance - with the power to shape it in ways that we struggle to comprehend. You cannot escape having an impact on others or the world around you, and doing nothing only threatens to have more of a negative impact than if you choose to take charge and decide what it is you want to effect.
None of us asked to be where we are or to exist at all, and sometimes life throws us in directions we don't want to turn or down paths that are painful to tread, but since we've only been given this one chance we can't turn back, only move forward, and whether you choose to do that lying on your back or not, the world's going to keep on turning. Care for yourself because you have the ability to shape these things: your personality, your self-worth and the actions you take. So you're wrong: anyone born in your shoes could be in a different place, because they could make the conscious choice to do something different, as can you.
Believe me, I've asked all the same questions you're asking once before: my disability, thrust on me by chance, has led to many horrible challenges in life: I've been bullied, physically and mentally abused, tormented by my own self-loathing and struggling to fit into a society which still does not fully consider me to be a part of it, either in terms of the physical space in which we live or in the mental consciousness. This has led me at times to be a very upset and irritable person, leading to broken hearts and friendships. Many times I've wondered why I should bother to keep going or engage if all I am is such a burden, and whether the world would indeed just be a better place if I wasn't here.
Now I say, no more. I cannot change what has happened to me in the past: the things that have been done to me, what I've done to myself and to others, but I can choose who and what I want to be. I've chosen to use the life I've been given to make the world a better place, so that people - like me or not - should not have to suffer in the same ways that I have done. I want to enrich peoples lives by helping them understand their history and through that understanding themselves. This is why I will one day be Director of the British Museum, why I consciously choose to love and embrace others - faults and all - because it means I am better at loving myself, and that no matter how small, I will always choose to help rather than ignore. You can do the same, or not, but the choice is ultimately yours to make.
It's impossible to put into any kind of words how much you must possibly mean to your family, friends and loved ones. Do not try to search for those words but instead open yourself to those feelings and those emotions, and in feeling them you can begin to feel for yourself. The road will be long and hard and I cannot predict for you what might happen along the way, but I can promise you that whatever happens, it's better to be there for then to hide away and miss it all.
I hope to see you out on the road again soon, because you've got a long journey ahead of you.

text:
#UCLove19921
Its been a while since I've posted one of my positivity posts but It's hard to stay positive sometimes.
It is sometimes easier to suffer in silence, to withdraw from the people you care about and to suffer alone whilst pretending daily that everything is ok. I have done so myself. But it doesn't help. I was never taught to display or discuss my emotions and my parents never did. I taught myself to be strong but I didn't even know what strength was. Strength isn't suffering in silence, strength is overcoming difficulties and obstacles. It's having something good to say even on a bad day. This positivity post is dedicated to everyone who feels like life isn't going their way and those that feel like each day is more difficult to go through then yesterday.
We are constantly told what type of life we should lead. We are fed the ingredients to happiness and yet we are more depressed than ever. Why do we keep pretending? Happiness isn't a fancy car or a new house, it isn't nights out or nights in. Happiness isn't truly captured in photos, snapchats or screenshots. It's about being content, reflecting on what we have, removing negativity and accepting that although we may not be happy in this moment, that no-one is constantly happy. We are taught that some people live 'the life' but remember smiling to the world is easy when you aren't being watched at night. No-one sees the tears, the fights or even the roughest nights, they just see the smiles and believe that it represents your current state of mind. Point is, no-ones life is easy and we shouldn't pretend ours is either.

text:
#UCLove19338
For those of you students who are still having trouble with accommodation for the upcoming academic year, I have an alternative option for you. I have in a 3-bedroom house in Chelsea, close to Sloane Square tube station. In my garden, there is a shed, with a photo attached below. As you can see, it is a delightful shed, complete with two windows, a door and wooden flooring. It has the approval of shed connoisseurs such as James May and Alan Titchmarsh. I am offering you the opportunity to rent out my shed as living quarters from July 2018 to June 2019.
You will be allowed to decorate the shed as you please as long as you do not damage it and have no electrical appliances stored inside of it. In there at the moment is a sleeping bag, one pillow, some spare wood and a toolkit. You are free to use the wood and toolkit to furnish a desk and/or chair for yourself to complete your work on. Also, if you dare ruin the plants on the windows, I will hunt you down and end your pitiful existence.
You sure as hell aren't using my toilets or kitchens so you'll need to use public toilets and find your own way of feeding yourself and some other place or way to remove excrement. If you take a dump in my garden I will permanently relocate you to my basement to accommodate my legion of foreign sex slaves. I also have a decibel meter installed on my garden door; if it gets too high I will give you a warning - 3 strikes and you're out. While you are a guest, you will also be expected to wash my cars once every two months and make sure the police don't catch me and my human trafficking operation. In return, your curfew start time will be increased from 8pm to 10pm.
Prices start at Â£340 p/person p/week but I can be flexible.
Life in a shed is a unique and resounding experience so if you're interested, comment below and I'll send you some more information.

Dear UCLove folks,
Are you of the first generation in your family to go to uni? Are you at UCL or a recent graduate? If so, we are working on a research project that looks into the different experiences of first generation university students, and if you had some time and were interested in a chat and a coffee, we would love to interview you and hear all about your time at uni! If you think you might be interested, fill out this quick survey: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd5ZsMujnRwEEQD2QPzIBILJ9htNsnDfijXFov1p2V5RSTRdg/viewform?usp=pp_url
If you would prefer to talk to us directly, just leave a comment under this status and we can message you!
We look forward to hearing anything you have to say!

In reply to #UCLove18727 ,
The fact that girls are interested in you when your physique doesnâ€™t change, but your attitude does, is the proof that you donâ€™t need to doubt yourself and your looks so much. Iâ€™ve seen so many â€œaverage lookingâ€ guys get more girls than the typical â€œgood looking guyâ€, because in the end itâ€™s all down to how you feel about yourself, and the way you act/speak in result. Donâ€™t think about your looks so much, because apparently itâ€™s not the issue here, since you have no problem hitting it off with girls (suggesting that youâ€™re not as bad looking as you might think).
Maybe try practising talking to girls without alcohol, even if sometimes you have to pretend that you are self confident. Iâ€™m a very shy person myself, and pushing myself to talk to people and â€œfakingâ€ self confidence at the beginning helps me being more natural after a few minutes of conversation (because people will always react well, making me feel more comfortable). And in the long run, it has truly helped me engaging with others and not feeling as scared anymore, because I understood that there is no reason to not feel confident. I know itâ€™s hard work and youâ€™ll need some courage at the start but honestly, try relying on alcohol less and more on yourself (you will have to at some point anyway so might as well start early). With time you will see that girls donâ€™t react differently whether you drank or not, but only depending on your personality and theirs. Looks matter (and apparently yours are good enough to let you hit it off with girls easily), but not as much as attitude and conversation, which you can work on without alcohol.
Hope this helps x

Just using this page to promote the role of pharmacists in the healthcare sector. I feel like we're very often misinterpreted as "not doing much". I'd just like to point out that we do know how to do things beyond presented in a community pharmacy setting! We're pretty cool too! Please be nicer to your pharmacists and other staff in the pharmacy, we just want to help. Please stop yelling at us because your GP hasn't sent your prescription over to us causing a delay in dispensing. We just want you all to be healthy and aware of health complications! Please respect us a little! Have a good day!

I need help. I can't stop thinking about this guy. He's super sweet and really handsome. He's always smiling and super friendly, and even though I'm always super nervous to talk to him (because he's also really intelligent and perceptive), he's always so kind to me.
The problem is, he's taken. He's very taken. I have no chance. But even though he's taken and it's so obvious that he'd never choose me over his significant other, I still really deeply admire him. I get butterflies in my stomach when I think of him, I get really jumpy and excited when I see him. I've practically had this crush since the beginning of term, and cannot stop stalking his social media. How do I get over him?

text:
#UCLove7795
Tbh Paramore were really snubbed at the Grammys and I'm still mad, After Laughter was a work of pure genius. We got one half of the Farro brothers back, but little did we know that Hayley's marriage was virtually over and that she's been dealing with major anxiety over the past 3 years after selftitled reached major pop radio highs and she's afraid she has peaked - her lyrics were raw, honest and totally heartbreaking, while the synths and beats throughout were totally bop-worthy. Every time you listen through again, you hear something new and and realise just how much betrayal and just pure shit she's had to take from men in her life for the past decade. Just the fact that so many tracks sound happy while having lyrics that are depressing as hell is so damn poetic and I relate to it so deeply. 2017 was the year of revival for old pop punk and emo bands, and Paramore definately led the way, I'm so sad they didn't receive the recognition they deserved.
post_text:
#UCLove7795

Every time you listen through again, you hear something new and and realise just how much betrayal and just pure shit she's had to take from men in her life for the past decade. Just the fact that so many tracks sound happy while having lyrics that are depressing as hell is so damn poetic and I relate to it so deeply. 2017 was the year of revival for old pop punk and emo bands, and Paramore definately led the way, I'm so sad they didn't receive the recognition they deserved.

WE'RE MAKING SOME CHANGES TO OUR SUBMISSION SYSTEM!!!!
Lately UCLove hasn't been receiving...well..much love! But we want to make it easier for everyone to get involved, so we've set up a new submission system! (Shoutout to the lovely person who sent a message with this page in it - you're a lifesaver!) Just click the link below to send your confessions anonymously! We hope this makes things easier for you (and us.) Again, no offensive messages will be tolerated.
- lots of love
